chapter shall be and are incorporated by reference as the governing rules and procedures for the special assessment commission so created by this chapter part 1991 historical preservation commission purpose a the purpose of this chapter is to establish a program for the preservation protection and regulation of historic properties within the city for the educational cultural economic and general welfare of the public  to safeguard the heritage of the city by preserving and regulating historic properties which reflect elements of its cultural social economic political and architectural history  to preserve the citys economic base by the stimulation of the tourist industry  to establish and improve property values  to foster economic development  to manage growth  to foster civic pride in the beauty and noble accomplishments of the past  and to promote the use of historic properties for the education pleasure and welfare of the people of the city b it is intended that the commission will cooperate with and assist various local state and federal entities andor agencies in the enforcement of federal and state legislation to identify evaluate designate record protect and preserve properties significant in the prehistory history architecture engineering and culture of the community state and nation c it is further declared that the purposes of this chapter are to 1 retain and enhance those historic properties within the city while allowing their adaption for current use by assuring that alterations are compatible with their historic character  and 2 assure that new construction and subdivision of lots in historic districts ie concentrations of historic properties are compatible with the character of such districts  1990   preservation commissioncreated there is created a commission to be known as the city historical preservation commission  1990   commission membersnumberappointmenttermscompensation a numbers the commission shall consist of no less than five members and up to and including eight members b appointment the commission members shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city commission c terms each of the members of the commission shall be appointed for a term of two years and such terms shall be staggered d compensation the members shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed for expenses necessarily incurred in the performance of their duties    1990   member qualifications members appointed by the mayor shall be persons who in the opinion of the mayor have demonstrated outstanding interest and knowledge of history or architecture a majority of the commission members shall be made up of persons from among professionals in the disciplines of architecture history architectural history art history planning engineering archeology or other historic preservation related disciplines such as urban planning american studies american civilization cultural geography or cultural anthropology to the extent that such professionals are available in the community  1990   selection of chairperson the mayor shall designate one of the members of the commission to be chairperson and one to be vicechairperson  1990   authorization to conduct studies and surveys the commission shall have the authority to conduct or to have conducted on its behalf studies andor surveys of properties within the city limits the commission shall conduct such studies andor surveys in accordance with guidelines recommended by the state historical society all collected data shall be recorded and maintained copies of such data must be provided to the state historical society  1990   commission powers a unless otherwise specified herein the powers and duties of the commission shall be to 1 promulgate criteria for classifying properties within the city as having historic significance  2 prepare or have prepared on its behalf a comprehensive inventory of historically significant and potentially historically significant properties within the city  3 make recommendations to the city commission concerning the acquisition of fee simple and less than fee simple rights in properties within the city for purposes of historic preservation  4 make recommendations to the city commission for any additional ordinances andor administrative procedures required to implement the public policy declared in   5 develop and participate in public programs to increase public awareness of the value of historic properties and of the preservation program established by this chapter  6 make recommendations to the city commission i regarding application for and acceptance and utilization of grants from federal state and local agencies or other entities private groups and individuals and ii for budgetary appropriations to promote and achieve the preservation of historic properties in the city and to otherwise implement the public policy declared in this chapter  7 evaluate and comment upon plans proposals permits and applications which are developed or required by federal state municipal agencies or other public agencies including those developed by other commissions offices and departments of the city which may affect either directly or indirectly any property or properties deemed by the commission to have historic value  8 prepare and submit in accordance with all applicable federal and state laws and regulations nominations to the national register of historic places for properties deemed by the commission to be significant in local state andor natural history  9 review and comment upon all certifications of significance and certifications of rehabilitation as requested by the state historic preservation officer  and 10 perform any other functions which may be designated to it by resolution or motion of the city commission  1990   power to adopt rules of procedure the commission shall have the power to make whatever rules are necessary for the execution of its duties as set forth in this article all such rules shall be approved by the city commission by resolution before becoming effective  1990   meetingsnoticeminutes a the commission shall meet not less than four times annually according to a schedule established one year in advance the commission may meet at such other times as deemed convenient prudent and necessary by the commission b all commission meetings shall be open to the public and advertised not less than ten days in advance of the meeting c minutes of all meetings shall be maintained and kept in the office of the mayor and shall be provided to the state historical society within sixty days following each commission meeting or at such other times as may be directed  1990   authority to employ staff and services within the limit of funds appropriated generally for the performance of its work the commission may obtain the services of qualified persons to direct advise and assist the commission and may obtain the equipment supplies services and other material necessary to its effective operation  1990   authority to receive funding the city commission may annually appropriate funds within budget limitations for the operation of the city historical preservation commission a fund known as historical preservation will be created as a trust and agency fund all revenue from any source will be deposited in this fund the city historical preservation commission may receive revenues and turn them in to the city auditor for deposit into this fund the city historical preservation commission shall make recommendations for expenditures they deem necessary to the city commission all expenditures from this fund will be disbursed in the customary and usual manner as other disbursements are handled by city policy and procedures  1990 shade tree committee title this chapter shall be known and may be cited as the municipal shade tree ordinance of the municipality of devils lake county of ramsey state of north dakota  1980   definitions for the purpose of this chapter the following terms phrases words and their derivations shall have the meanings given in this section when not inconsistent with the context words used in the present tense include the future words in the plural include the singular and words in the singular include the plural the word shall is mandatory and not merely directive a forestry department is that department that works under the supervision of the shade tree committee of the municipality under whose jurisdiction cityowned trees fall b large trees mean those attaining a height of fortyfive feet or more c medium trees mean those attaining a height of thirty to fortyfive feet d municipality is the city town village subdivision or otherwise designated area unit of devils lake county of ramsey state of north dakota e nuisance means any dangerous or unsafe tree or portions thereof  and any tree harboring insect or disease organisms of a contagious and fatal nature which pose a serious threat to surrounding trees if not immediately removed and disposed of f park means and includes all public parks having individual names g person is any person firm partnership association corporation company or organization of any kind h property line means the outer edge of a street highway or other public places owned by the city i property owner means the person owning such property as shown by the county auditors plat of ramsey county state of north dakota j public places means and includes all other grounds owned by the municipality of devils lake county of ramsey state of north dakota k public trees means and includes all shade and ornamental trees now or hereafter growing on any street or any public place where otherwise indicated l shade tree foreman means the forester tree warden or other qualified official of the municipality of devils lake county of ramsey assigned to carry out the enforcement of this chapter under the supervision of the shade tree committee m small trees mean those attaining a height of twenty to thirty feet n street or highway means the entire width of every public way or rightofway when any part of it is open to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular and pedestrian traffic o tree lawn means that part of a street or highway not covered by a sidewalk or other paving lying between the property line and that portion of the street or highway usually used for vehicular traffic  1980   established a there shall be a committee known as the shade tree committee of devils lake composed of ten citizens the members shall be appointed by the mayor with approval of the city commission the majority of the members of the shade tree committee shall be residents of the city the committee shall consist of the following or a similar composition 1 one member of the city commission  2 one member of the planning commission  3 one staff member of the city as named by the city commission  4 one representative of a licensed local nursery or greenhouse  5 one representative of public utilities  6 one representative of the north dakota state university bottineau school of forestry or other recognized school of forestry or horticulture  7 no less than four and no more than six citizens at large b terms shall be for three years upon adoption the initial terms shall be a continuation of the terms under the previous shade tree ordinance the slate of officers shall also be carried over from the committee under the previous shade tree ordinance vacancies caused by death resignation or otherwise shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as original appointments are made all members of the committee shall serve without compensation   part 2000    i 1980   powers and duties the duties of the shade tree committee shall be as follows a to study the problems and determine the needs of the municipality of devils lake county of ramsey state of north dakota in connection with its tree planting and maintenance program  b to recommend to the proper authority the type and kind of trees to be planted on the rightofway or berm which include but are not limited to canadian red cherry tree burr oak linden ash and seedless cottonwood other species may be permitted by the forester granting a written permit conifers shrubs and similar plantings shall not be acceptable for rightofway plantings  c to assist the properly constituted officials of the municipality as well as the commission and citizens of the municipality in the dissemination of news and information regarding the selection planting and maintenance of trees within the corporate limits whether it is on private or public property and to make such recommendations from time to time to the city commission as to de sirable legislation concerning the tree program and activities for the municipality  d to provide regular and special meetings at which the subject of trees insofar as it relates to the municipality may be discussed by members of the committee officers and personnel of the municipality and its several divisions and all others interested in the tree program part 2000  ii 1980   foremanappointment and salary the shade tree foreman shall be appointed by the city commission upon the recommendation of the shade tree committee and shall receive a salary commensurate with his training and experience as full compensation for all services rendered and in lieu of all fees  1980   foremanduties the shade tree foreman under the direction of the shade tree committee has municipality he shall cause the provision of this chapter to be enforced in his absence these duties shall be the responsibility of a qualified alternate designated by the shade tree committee  1980 property any personal property abandoned or left unclaimed upon the streets alleys or other public ways of the city for a period exceeding ten days shall be taken up by any police officer of the city in be kept in the office of the police department with the date of such taking  1958   redemption by owner any person who satisfactorily establishes that he is the owner thereof may reclaim any such articles of personal property from the chief of police thereof as set forth in this chapter upon payment to the city treasurer of the necessary expenses of taking and storing payment to be certified to by the chief of police  1958   sale of abandoned property whenever in the judgment of the chief of police sufficient articles have been accumulated and held for a period of sixty days or more to justify the expense of a sale thereof the articles may be sold by the chief of police at public auction each item of property which has been held by the police department for more than sixty days shall be sold to the highest bidder for cash and the chief of police shall convey to the purchaser by bill of sale title to the property accurate records of each sale shall be kept showing the price for which each article was sold  1958   notice of sale notice of time and place of sale and a brief description of the articles to be sold shall be published not less than ten days prior to the date of sale  1958   owner entitled to proceeds of sale a at any time within six months after the sale the owner of the property upon written application shall be entitled to receive the proceeds of the sale less the necessary expenses of taking storing and selling them b applications for repayment by the owner of any such property shall be filed with the city auditor and passed on by the city commission  1980   report and remittance of funds to commission immediately after a sale the chief of police shall report to the city commission his proceedings upon the sale together with the price of each article sold and shall remit to the city treasurer the entire proceeds of the sale  1980 municipal airport vehicles not to interfere with takeoff and landing of aircraft no one shall drive or cause to be driven any vehicle other than an aircraft upon the runways taxiways or aircraft parking ramps at the municipal airport or at any place thereon which will interfere with the taking off or landing of aircraft at the airport except authorized repair and maintenance men  1968   livestock running loose prohibited no one shall permit livestock to run loose upon the municipal airport nor shall any animal be driven upon the runways taxiways or parking ramps of the airport  1968   lessee to keep premises in neat condition any lessee of a site upon the municipal airport shall keep the hangar  1968 airport regulations general provisions a designated representative the airport manager shall be the designated representative of the devils lake municipal airport authority to enforce the regulations and ordinances provided for in the devils lake municipal airport standard operating procedures and any city ordinances the airport manager is authorized to administer fines and corrections in accordance with this chapter of the municipal code b hunting or shooting within boundaries of airport hunting or shooting within the boundaries of the airport is strictly prohibited other than wildlife control that is deemed necessary by the airport manager or designee no persons except law enforcement officers members of the armed forces of the united states on official duty or persons duly authorized by the devils lake municipal airport authority shall carry any weapons explosive material or hazardous material on the airport except cased sporting firearms carried for transshipment or in locked racks covered under the north dakota century public nuisance no person shall be or become intoxicated commit any disorderly obscene or indecent act or commit any action of nuisance destroy injure deface or disturb in any way any building sign equipment marker light fixture or other structure or property in the airport d advertisement no person may post distribute or display a sign advertisement circular or other written or printed matter in the airport without the permission of the airport manager part 2005   commercial activity a general no person shall use the airport for commercial activities without a written contractual arrangement with the airport authority and the holder of a commercial lease at the airport will be authorized to conduct only those legal commercial activities that are approved in the commercial lease commercial activities shall include but are not limited to carrying passengers for hire flight instruction aircraft rental sales of goods and services agricultural operations and aircraft maintenance and repairs any individual owner of aircraft or where joint ownership exits which engages in these activities for hire shall be considered to be engaged in commercial activities b commercial authorization all commercial aviation activities shall be authorized by the airport authority in accordance with all local city and federal regulations c nondiscrimination any commercial operation engaged in providing services to the public shall perform those services in a fair equal safe and legal manner and shall not discriminate against any user but shall make reasonable and nondiscriminatory all pricing discounts rebates or other price reductions to volume customers d fuel no aviation fuels shall be brought in the airport for use or for sale without the expressed permission of the airport authority this permission is to be granted in a written document providing for safety in storage and handling all fueling performed on the airport must be in accordance with the 14 cfr of the federal aviation regulations e aerial application any person using the airport as a base for agricultural aerial application which involves the loading unloading and storage of chemical must receive a permit from the airport authority this permit will specify the areas to be used restrictions which will apply and the payment of an operating fee no permit will be granted for less than a thirtyday period spraying operations are strictly prohibited on taxiways runways and other controlled areas part 2005   leases a general all tenants shall be required to maintain their lease property in a condition of cleanliness and free from all fire hazards and shall dispose of garbage refuse or other material in the receptacles approved for that purpose no tenants lessees or grantees will be permitted to affect structural or decorative changes or additions of any type without submitting plans to the city assessorbuilding official for review and obtaining prior permission of the airport authority tenants and their lessees and grantees shall be fully responsible for all damages to buildings equipment real property and appurtenances in the ownership or custody of the airport caused by their negligence or abuse of carelessness b property improvement no person shall use occupy improve or construct any structure on any part or portion of the airport without first submitting plans to the city assessorbuilding official for review approval and issuance of any necessary building permit and have secured written permission from the airport authority c construction no person shall construct erect or install any building or improvements upon any of the lots at the airport without first securing written permission from the airport authority a proper building permit must be obtained from the city assessorbuilding official and any required faa for including faa form no 74601 shall be completed and submitted to both the faa and the airport manager for review before any construction is commenced the airport authority shall have the right to inspect the plans and specifications of any such buildings structures and improvements prior to construction or maintenance the airport authority reserve the right to refuse such construction or maintenance if the external appearance does not meet reasonable requirements for substantial uniformity of appearance of all buildings and structures on the airport or if the type of construction or installation or the location does not meet reasonable requirements for safe use of the airport and appurtenances part 2005   vehicle regulations a vehicle authorization only authorized vehicles that have been certified by the airport manager and are in possession of a valid airport operations security badge will be permitted to drive on the apron or other controlled area in the airport airport operation security badges will be issued by the airport manager upon successful completion of any requirements set out by the airport authority and may be suspended or revoked at any time by the airport authority b unauthorized vehicles no private vehicle shall be driven onto the ramp except as necessary to go directly to and from specific aircraft for loading and unloading baggage or other special purposes and must be escorted by an authorized vehicle driven by personnel in possession of a valid airport operation security badge c twowheeled vehicles no person may operate a bicycle or a twowheeled motor vehicle on the landing area or ramp in the airport d speed limit no unauthorized vehicle other than airport maintenance or faa personnel equipped with a unicom and whose vehicle has a flashing light mounted on the roof may operate a motor vehicle at a speed of more than ten miles an hour on any taxiway runway restricted service road or other aircraft movement area e operational control no person may operate a motor vehicle in the airport in a careless or reckless manner as to endanger the life or property of others each person operating a motor vehicle in the airport will have a valid operators license and shall operate it so as to have it under proper control at all times f parking no person may park or stand a motor vehicle in the airport except in an area specifically designated for parking or standing no person may park a motor vehicle in any area in the airport for a period longer than is designated for that area no person may park or stand a motor vehicle within ten feet of a water hydrant in the airport g removal the airport authority or its authorized representatives may tow away or move any motor vehicle in the airport that is parked in violation of the regulations of the airport any vehicle equipment mobile structure trailer or boat without any specific aviation use or abandoned property left for a period of more than seventytwo hours will be removed the airport may charge a reasonable amount for the moving service and for storage of the vehicle equipment mobile structure trailer or boat if any the moved property is subject to a lien for reasonable charges h large vehicles any vehicles larger than a oneton truck excluding buses used to transport passengers to and from the airport terminal are prohibited from driving or parking on the streets or parking lots restricted by the airport authority i traffic vehicles operating in the airport are subject to the provisions of the city traffic code part 2005   aircraft regulations a general all aircraft operating on the devils lake airport shall conform with all rules and regulations set by the federal aviation administration and shall only operate on those areas designated for aircraft use unless otherwise permitted in writing by the airport authority b aircraft parking all aircraft parked on the airport whether temporary or permanent shall be parked only in assigned or designated parking areas aircraft not parked in the proper area will be notified if possible and will be given twentyfour hours in which to move the aircraft to an authorized parking area c minor maintenance only minor maintenance or repairs excluding fluid changes oil hydraulics battery acid coolant etc will be performed on aircraft parked on the ramp of the airport except when necessary to move the aircraft to a designated maintenance facility d securing of aircraft the operator of each aircraft permanently based and parked on the airport will be responsible for properly securing the aircraft to protect it and other aircraft from wind damage individual airplanes may tie down in designated and established tiedown areas the airport authority airport manager or authorized agent of the airport shall not provide tiedown restraints including ropes chains etc  nor shall the airport authority airport manager or authorized agent be responsible to the owner of any aircraft for any damage sustained to such aircraft while using the tiedown space a schedule of fees for tiedowns may be established by the airport authority if so deemed necessary e engine warming aircraft engines will be warmed up only in places normally approved for such purpose at no time will aircraft with engines running be left unattended by any person at no time shall engines be warmed up or operated when hangars shops offices buildings persons equipment passengers or aircraft are in the path of the propeller stream or turbine engine exhaust part 2005   fire regulations a fueling no aircraft shall be fueled or drained while its engine is running or while in a hangar or other enclosed place except for maintenance purposes fueling shall be done in accordance with 14 cfr of the federal aviation regulations as amended and in such a manner and with such equipment that adequate connections for the grounding of static electricity shall be continuously maintained during such time no person shall perform or allow performance of any refueling operation during an electrical wind or dust storm b hazardous materials no fuels oils dopes paints solvents chemicals acids or other hazardous material shall be disposed of or dumped in drains on the ramp area catch basins ditches or elsewhere in the airport c explosives no person shall store keep use dispose or transport to in or upon the airport any class a or class b explosives as defined in the icc regulations for transportation of explosive and other dangerous articles dynamite nitroglycerine black powder fireworks alcohol ether liquid shellac kerosene turpentine or other flammable or combustible liquids ammonium nitrate sodium chlorate powdered metallic magnesium or other easily flammable solids corrosive liquids or gas any radioactive article substance or other hazardous material prohibited by the transportation security administration tsa at such time or place or in such manner or condition as to endanger unreasonably or as to be likely to endanger unreasonably persons or property part 2005   airport safety any accident or emergency shall be reported to the lake region law enforcement center and the airport manager immediately no unauthorized personnel shall go to the scene of an accident except to render aid in the absence of authorized personnel part 2005   terminal use a general the corridor and lobby areas of the terminal shall be open to all airport tenants and airline customers as long as the terminal is open all private areas in the terminal tsa screening rooms airline offices etc shall be occupied at the will of their perspective owners and shall be closed to public use unless otherwise authorized by the owner unauthorized use of the terminal is prohibited unless written authorization is obtained by the airport authority b smoking terminal facilities as with all public facilities shall be smoke free at all times c alcohol alcohol in the terminal facilities is strictly prohibited unless specifically authorized by the airport authority d animals dogs cats birds wild animals rodents and other animals are prohibited in the terminal building unless the animal is authorized to be transported on an aircraft and the animal is properly caged andor restrained this does not include any dog used to assist someone who is vision impaired part 2005   enforcement a general any person who knowingly and wilfully violates any rule or regulation prescribed in these regulations or any order or instruction issued by the devils lake municipal airport authority authorized in this chapter may be fined and or ejected from the airport and may be denied the use of the airport and its facilities if it is determined by the airport authority that such denial is necessary under the circumstances an act is done knowingly if it is done voluntarily and intentionally and not because of mistake or accident or other innocent reason an act is done wilfully if done voluntarily and intentionally and with the intent to do something which the actor knows the regulations forbid b fines the airport manager or the airport authority has the authority to impose fines for any violation of this chapter of the devils lake municipal fine shall be one hundred dollars for each violation each day in which a violation occurs is a separate violation resulting to one hundred dollars per day fine a fine is imposed by written notification to the party against whom the fine is imposed the party has ten days in which to appeal the decision of the fine to the airport authority the failure to appeal the imposition of the fine or the decision of the airport authority on the fine shall be final c denial of use any party may be denied of use of the airport by action of the airport authority if the airport manager or the airport authority feels such action is necessary notice shall be provided to the party whose privileges are sought to be denied the notice shall specify the actions of the party considered to be such that the partys privileges may be denied and the date time and place when the airport authority will conduct a hearing on the denial of the privileges the hearing will be in no less than seven or more than fourteen days from the date of the notice the violation of any provision of this chapter shall be sufficient cause to deny a party the right to use the airport the failure to pay a fine imposed in subsection b of this section is sufficient grounds to deny a party of the use of the airport the airport authority may dismiss the matter suspend the partys use of the airport for a period of time impose such conditions on the partys use of the airport if it feels necessary or suspend and deny the partys use of the airport the decision of the airport authority shall be final part 2005 city cemetery designated the land and property acquired by the city from the gar cemetery association and st josephs church of devils lake together with all additions to it shall be known as the devils lake cemetery  1948   maintained for inhabitants the cemetery shall be maintained as a burial ground for the inhabitants of the city and for such other persons as the city commission may by ordinance or resolution permit to be buried in it  1948   interment within city prohibited no interment of any deceased person shall be made within the city  1948   preferred right of burial to roman catholics on certain premises persons dying in the roman catholic faith shall have a preferred right to burial on the premises deeded by st josephs church ministers of all faiths may conduct funeral services within the cemetery in accordance with the rituals of their respective faiths membership or nonmembership in any faith however shall not affect the right to burial in any part of the cemetery  1948   recognition of rights of owners of burial lots the rights of all owners of burial lots or burial rights heretofore made by the respective owners of the cemetery property shall be recognized and the title is accepted by the city subject to all burial rights heretofore granted  1948   platting portions of the cemetery have heretofore been platted and the plats are recognized and additional portions of the cemetery shall be platted from time to time as may be found necessary the plots are laid out in blocks lots and single grave rights  1948   purchase of grave sites by residents and nonresidents a any resident of the city or nonresident owning property and paying property taxes within the city may purchase one or more single grave sites at the city cemetery the number of such grave sites may be limited by the superintendent or other official of the city to such number as the purchaser may reasonably use for his immediate family any person who has shown a bonafide intent to become a permanent resident of the city by residing in the city for ninety days or more shall be deemed a resident for the purpose of this chapter the ordinance codified in this section shall be in full force and effect after its passage and approval as provided by law b nonresidents of the city may purchase one or more single grave sites within the city cemetery as long as the superintendent or other official of the city deems the facilities ample to provide for the future requirements of the residents of the city any person who moves from the city after establishing residence in it shall be deemed a resident until the person has established residence elsewhere c the date of burial or cremation shall be the date of the committal service north dakota century  bodies may be stored in the storage vault at the cemetery from the date of the committal service to the date of interment     part 1981 part 1973 part 1968 part 1965   fees the fees to be charged for burial rights grave openings and other services shall be established by resolution of the city commission and revised as it may see fit part 1981  part 1973 part 1968  part 1965   burial of infants persons desiring to bury infants in the cemetery may with the approval of the superintendent purchase less than a single grave right and in such case appropriate notation shall be made by the superintendent on his records  1948   burial of more than one person in single grave not more than one person shall be buried in any single grave right except in the case of infants  1948   no title to land to purchasers of grave rights purchasers of grave rights shall acquire only the right to make interment in the space purchased and shall acquire no title to the land  1948   superintendentoffice created there is created the office of superintendent of cemetery the superintendent shall be appointed by the president of the board of city commissioners for a term of two years the same person may be appointed as assessor of the city and as superintendent of the cemetery  1948   superintendentreceipt to purchaser for grave rights the superintendent shall issue to the purchaser of all grave rights a receipt specifying the amount of money paid by the purchaser and designating the specific grave rights in which burial may be made one copy of the receipt shall be delivered to the purchaser and one copy shall be furnished to the city auditor while one copy shall be retained by the superintendent  1948   moneys received credited to cemetery fund all moneys received from the sale of lots or grave rights and all other moneys received under the provisions of this chapter shall be credited to the cemetery fund of the city all expenditures for the maintenance of the cemetery shall be paid out of such fund upon vouchers properly certified and approved by the superintendent  1948   certificate procured for interment when the owner of any grave right desires to have interment made the owner or his representatives shall procure from the superintendent a certificate designating the specific grave right in which interment will be made and he shall pay to the superintendent the sum of fifty cents for such certificate  1948   superintendentto keep records of grave rights it shall be the duty of the superintendent to keep adequate and sufficient records to readily show who are the owners of grave rights which have been sold and also to show the particular grave rights in which interment has been made and who has been buried therein and to comply with all laws of the state and regulations of the state health department with reference to burial permits and the keeping of records in connection with burials in the cemetery  1948   superintendentsalary the salary of the superintendent shall be fixed by the board of city commissioners from time to time and in the event the same person may hold another appointment under the city his salary may be apportioned among the several departments served as the board of city commissioners may determine  1948   superintendentjurisdiction the superintendent shall have general jurisdiction over the cemetery and shall supervise the digging of graves the placing of monuments the planting of trees and shrubbery the erection of improvements and the general management of the cemetery  1948   superintendentpower to make rules subject to the provisions of this chapter and such ordinances and resolutions as may be adopted by the board of city commissioners the superintendent shall have the power to make such reasonable rules and regulations as he may deem necessary with reference to the use care and improvement of the cemetery  1948   superintendentmay employ assistants the superintendent subject to approval by the board of city commissioners may employ such assistance as may be required for the operation and management of the cemetery and shall direct the activities of such employees  1948   superintendentopening of grave all graves shall be opened under the direction of the superintendent when a certificate for burial is issued by him he shall collect from the person desiring to make interment an amount sufficient to pay for the opening of a grave the amount shall be determined from time to time by the superintendent with the approval of the board of city commissioners the superintendent at his discretion may permit the person desiring to make interment to himself open the grave or hire the opening to be made  1948   superintendentadditional platting and land set aside for chapels the superintendent shall cause additional portions of the cemetery to be platted from time to time as need may occur upon application of any church within the city he may set aside a portion of the cemetery to be occupied by a chapel to be erected by such church but all costs in connection with the erection or maintenance of such chapel shall be borne by such church and it and the surrounding grounds must be maintained in good condition  1948   use regulations for burial vaults the burial vault at the cemetery may be used for the storage of cemetery equipment but otherwise shall be used exclusively for storing dead bodies during such time as it is impracticable to make interment in the cemetery and such storage shall be made without discrimination such storage shall be made under the supervision of the superintendent and he may require any body to be removed from the vault and interred when conditions require  1948   construction of burial vaults all burial vaults used in the devils lake cemetery shall be constructed of permanent material which is acceptable by the state health department and meets the minimum requirements of any applicable federal or state law  provided however that certain exceptions to this section may be allowed in the event of religious beliefs contrary to the requirements specified in this section  1972   improperly installed monuments to be reset monuments and markers which are not properly installed or which constitute a hazard or are in an unsightly condition shall be reset by the employees of the cemetery when time and facilities permit the cost shall be charged to the lot owners and shall be collected before other burials are permitted in the lot belonging to such owner  1948   installation of monuments on concrete foundation installation of monuments and markers shall be made on a concrete foundation in such a manner as to assure the permanence and sightliness of the monument or marker and to facilitate the cutting of grass around it  1948   foundation installation supervised by superintendent all foundation work shall be done under the supervision of the superintendent he may direct such work to be done by regular employees or may engage persons qualified for the work individuals with experience in this work may do their own work with the permission and under the supervision of the superintendent  1948   fees for work and services fees for all work and services shall be fixed from time to time by the superintendent subject to approval by the board of city commissioners  1948   general regulations a no person shall disturb the quiet by noise of any kind or by any improper conduct b no person shall have in his possession or shall discharge any firearm in the cemetery except soldiers and veterans at military funerals and at memorial day services c no person shall drive any vehicle faster than ten miles per hour nor drive anywhere except on the roads d no person shall obstruct passage by parking on any road e no person shall loiter any place in the cemetery f no person shall remove any object or make any excavation without the express consent of the superintendent g no person shall wilfully injure or destroy any monument marker tree or decoration or commit any act of vandalism in the cemetery h no person shall leave or store any object or property in the cemetery which is not for immediate installation in it  1948 public library   definitions for the purposes of this chapter the board of city commissioners means the governing body of the city and the board of directors means the governing body of lake region public library part 1991    established there is organized and established for the city a public library to be known as lake region public library     taking of library materials against rules prohibited every person who takes from the public library any library materials pamphlet periodical paper audiovisual materials or other property except in accordance with the rules of the library shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished for each offense as provided in the fees and rates     late return of library materials prohibited every person who takes or borrows from the public library any library materials pamphlet periodical paper audiovisual materials or other property and who refuses or neglects to return it within three weeks from the date of mailing a notice of delinquency to the persons address and refuses or neglects during that time to pay the librarian the value of the property shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished for each offense as provided in the fees and rates     damage to library property prohibited every person who willfully and wantonly cuts mutilates marks tears writes upon defaces or otherwise destroys or injuries in whole or in part any library property pamphlet periodical map document picture audiovisual materials or written or engraved or printed paper belonging to the public library or suffers any such injury to be done while such property is in the persons custody or willfully or wantonly injures any of the furniture or property in the rooms or buildings occupied by the library shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine for each offense as provided in the fees and rates     fines all fines collected under this chapter shall be paid into the library fund for the use of the library  provided however that all costs due the city must be paid before any sums are paid into the library fund  and it shall be the duty of the city attorney to prosecute all violations of this chapter    library fund a for the purpose of maintaining a public library service the board of city commissioners has established a library fund the library fund consists of annually levying and causing to be collected as other taxes are collected a municipal tax not exceeding six mills as previously voted on by the electors and any other moneys received for library purposes from any source b the city auditor shall maintain the fund to account for library revenues and shall make payments from the fund for invoices that have been submitted and approved by the library board of directors on request of the city auditor the library board of directors shall supply its records the records must be provided on a timely basis the fund may not revert to the city at the end of any fiscal year the fund must be used exclusively for the maintenance of public library service c whenever a tax for county library service is levied the city auditor shall execute a written application to be exempted from the county tax levy for the property located within the city limits as allowed under the provisions of north dakota century part 1991   board of directors a the board of directors of the lake region public library shall consist of seven persons the board of city commissioners shall appoint four of those directors to govern the library of the four directors appointed by the city commission one of them shall be a member of the board of commissioners or designated as the representative of the board of city commissioners the remaining three members of the board of directors of the library shall be appointed by the ramsey county commission b the directors term of office shall be three years from the first day of july in the year of appointment and until a successor has been appointed no member shall serve for more than two consecutive terms after which an interval of one year must elapse before the same member may be reappointed c all vacancies on the board of directors shall be reported to the appointing board who shall appoint to the unexpired term for the residue only this unexpired term shall count as one of the two consecutive terms which a director is limited to serve d no compensation shall be paid or allowed to a director at the first meeting following the appointment of its members the board of directors shall meet and organize by electing a president e the board of city commissioners may contract directly with the library board established by another governing body of a municipality county or school board for the purpose of public library service  part 1991    general powers and duties the board of directors shall have the following powers and duties a to make and adopt such bylaws rules and regulations relating to the duties of their officers as may be expedient and not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter and file the same with the city auditor  b to make and adopt such bylaws rules and regulations for the management of the library as are expedient and not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter and file the same with the city auditor  c to control exclusively the expenditures of all moneys collected for or contributed to the library fund  d to have the supervision care and custody of the library property and of the rooms or buildings constructed leased or set apart for use of library purposes  e to contract to receive library service from other counties school districts cities and the state library  f to employ qualified personnel to administer the public library and dispense library services part 1991   library buildings a the board of directors with the approval of the board of city commissioners may build lease leasepurchase or purchase an appropriate building for a library and purchase a site therefor b prior to approval the board of city commissioners shall hold a public hearing notice of the hearing shall be published at least once not less than six days prior to the hearing in the official city newspaper c the board of city commissioners shall seek the advice and comment of the state library and the general public at the hearing after such hearing the board of city commissioners may establish by resolution a library building fund for the purpose of construction enlargement alteration of a building or for the purchase of an existing building to be used as a public library d the city auditor shall place in the library building fund all monies as may be appropriated or received for such purposes from any source e the library building fund shall not revert to the library general fund or the general fund of the city without authorization by formal resolution from both the library board of directors and the board of city commissioners part 1991    vouchers the city auditor may draw money from the library fund only upon vouchers approved by the board of directors without any other approval part 1991   library free to residents of ramsey county a the library established under this chapter and the services provided thereof shall be free to all residents of ramsey county subject to such reasonable rules and regulations as the board of directors may deem necessary to adopt to render the greatest benefit such rules shall be posted in a location readily accessible to the public the board may exclude from the use of the library any and all persons who willfully violate such rules b pursuant to north dakota century any person residing outside of ramsey county north dakota shall be considered a nonresident and shall be charged a fee for public library service the amount of which and duration of time paid for shall be determined by the library board of directors   part 1991    donations all persons desirous of making donations of money books personal property or real estate for the benefit of the library may vest the same in the board of directors the board of directors shall hold and control all property accepted for the use of the library as a special trustee part 1991   annual report of board of directors the board of directors shall make a report not later than for what purpose  d the number of books and other materials on hand  e the number of books and other materials added by purchase or gift during the year and the number thereof lost or loaned out  f the character and kind of materials contained in the library  g such other statistics information and suggestions or as may be required by the state library copies of the report shall be filed with the state library by the board of directors part 1991    open records exception any record maintained or received by the library which provides a patrons name or information sufficient to identify a century or any act amendatory to thereof shall be considered by the board of city commissioners  emergency employees purpose it is the purpose of this chapter to require emergency employees to reside within the city so that they are available to assist in emergency situations and that the response to emergency situations is timely given part 1997   definitions the following definitions shall apply to this chapter emergency employee means an employee of the public works department the fire department or the police department of the city of devils lake resident means a person who has their place of abode in the city of devils lake and is a bona fide resident of the city of devils lake a bona fide resident is a person having a permanent domicile within the city of devils lake and a domicile which has not been adopted with the intention of later moving back to a previous residence acquired outside of the city limits part 1997   residency requirements all emergency employees as a condition of their employment shall be residents of the city part 1997   exceptions to residency requirements residency requirements in this chapter do not apply to the following a emergency employees who on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter are not residents of the city this exception is not intended however to allow present emergency employees who are residents of the city to move their residence outside of the city after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter  b administration personnel not including department heads who are designated by their department head as an employee who is not required to be available in an emergency the department head is intended to be an emergency employee  c an emergency employee who does request in writing to be granted an exception to the residency requirement which request is granted by the city commission part 1997   effective date the ordinance codified in this chapter will be effective upon its adoption by the devils lake city commission part 1997 title 3  revenue and finance chapters utility bill utility bill a a utility bill consisting of charges for the service and usage of water sewer wastewater garbage and other charges authorized by the city commission shall be sent to each customer using any or all of these services monthly on a cycle basis b for all utilities the monthly charge shall be added to and collected as a part of the utility bill but each service shall be separately stated on the bill the proceeds from the collection of the fees and charges for each service shall be placed in the appropriate fund for each respectively c if the utility bill together with the penalty is not paid the city may maintain an action for the collection of such charges part 1992   special assessment of unpaid utility bill it shall be the duty of the city auditor to certify to the county auditor such unpaid utility bill in the same manner and at the same time as other assessments are certified and they shall be assessed and collected in the same manner part 1992   rates and charges rates shall be fixed from time to time by resolution of the governing body and the city reserves the part 1992   penalty a late charge shall be assessed according to the current resolution of fees and rates to all account amounts shown as previous balance part 1992   rates and chargesliability a the of premises where service is supplied shall notify the city auditors office in case any tenant moves from the premises prior to such moving c on request of the owner the city auditor will bill the occupant or tenant for such charges d if such charges are not paid within sixty days of the consumption period by the occupant or tenant the owner or owners shall be responsible for such charges part 1992   notice of discontinuance required any person desiring to discontinue the use of the water must give notice thereof at the office of the city auditor part 1992   billing method the method of billing shall be as follows a payment due twentyfive days after billing with shutoff sixty days after the consumption period b any account with an amount not paid within sixty days of the consumption period will receive a disconnect notice on the past due amount as shown on the utility billing this notice is sent to the renter and owner of the account as appropriate c if a city representative is sent to this account for shutoff or if water is shutoff a charge will be assessed to the account according to the current resolution of fees and rates any insufficient checks received as payment for a past due account will be an immediate disconnect part 1992   shutoff ordered whenever shutoff is ordered the days of tuesday wednesday or thursday will be utilized as much as possible this is intended to not shutoff on mondays fridays weekends or holidays part 1992   payment after shutoff ordered payment of the entire amount due including reconnect fee will be made prior to turning the service back chapter part 2006    sales tax imposed subject to the provisions of ndcc  06 and except as otherwise provided by this chapter or the sales and use tax laws of the state of north dakota a tax of two and one quarter percent is imposed upon the gross receipts of retailers from all sales at retail including the leasing or renting of tangible personal property within the corporate limits of the city of devils lake north dakota part 2006    use tax imposed subject to the provisions of ndcc  4005106 and except as otherwise provided in this chapter or the sales and use tax laws of the state of north dakota an excise tax is imposed upon the storage use or consumption within the corporate limits of the city of devils lake north dakota of tangible personal property purchased at retail for storage use or consumption in this city at the rate of two and one quarter percent of the purchase price of the property an excise tax is imposed on the storage use or consumption within the corporate limits of the city of devils lake north dakota of tangible personal property not originally purchased for storage use or consumption in this city at the rate of two and one quarter percent of the fair market value of the property at the time it was brought into this city part 2006    gross receipts of alcoholic beverages subject to the provisions of ndcc  4005106 and except as otherwise provided in this chapter a gross receipts tax of two and one quarter percent is imposed upon all gross receipts from the sale of alcoholic beverages within the city a person who receives alcoholic beverages for storage use or consumption in this state is subject to tax on storage use or consumption of those alcoholic beverages at the rate of two and one quarter percent part 2006    exemptions in addition to the exemptions provided by state law this chapter provides exemptions from imposition and computation of the city sales or use tax for sales of the following a sales of natural gas  b gross receipts from coinoperated amusement devices  c new farm machinery  d new farm irrigation equipment part 2006    contractors sales to contractors that are exempt pursuant to subsection 15 of ndcc  5739204 shall be exempt from any city sales tax but contractors shall be subject to the city use tax on those items used within the city that would be taxed pursuant to ndcc  57402033 on which the city sales items may obtain a refund of the excess tax payment by filing a request for refund upon the forms provided by the tax commissioner part 2006    contract with tax commissioner the devils lake city and in the absence of a valid contract with the tax commissioner or failure of the tax commissioner to perform the delegated duties shall perform these duties in place of the tax commissioner part 2006    dedication of tax proceeds the proceeds from the tax imposed by this chapter are hereby dedicated as follows a debt reduction for sewage treatment system property tax relief infrastructure 2005 water source definitions the city in this chapter is the city of devils lake north dakota part 2006   findings the adoption of this chapter is supported and based upon the following findings a the city is subject to a mandate from the federal government to have the arsenic level of its water in compliance with amounts acceptable to the federal government b the present water supply system of the city presently exceeds the normal life of a water supply system c the city has acquired the title to real property for the location of wells to provide a new water source for the city d the city has acquired the permits needed to use the water from these new well sites e the city has requested financial assistance from various sources to finance the acquisition construction and operation of a new water source f regional flooding has caused the present water supply line to be covered by significant amounts of lake water making rerouting routine maintenance and repairs extremely difficult and costly part 2006   enabling provision the city does operate under a home rule charter approved by the voters of the city at a special election held on  b of the home rule charter gives the city certain power provided as follows a to control its finances and fiscal affairs  to appropriate money for its purposes and make payment of its debts and expenses  to levy and collect taxes excises fees charges and special assessments for benefits conferred for its public and proprietary functions activities operations undertakings and improvements  to contract debts borrow money issue bonds warrants and other evidences of indebtedness  to establish charges for any city or other services and to establish debt and mill levy limitations  provided that all real and personal property in order to be subject to the assessment provisions of this subsection shall be assessed in a uniform manner and  provided further that the mill levies ordered imposed by the governing body on taxable property subject to ad valorem taxation shall not exceed in total the sum of levies authorized by state statutes and the constitution for cities of similar classification to that of the city of devils lake however same may be budgeted for any city purposes the governing body shall be permitted to promulgate the city budget without regard to the specific dedications of mill levies to specific purposes as long as the total budget is not more than the total amount of mills authorized to be levied by a city part 2006   funding the city will fund the purchase of the well sites the construction of the pumps water lines treatment plant and any other necessary equipment for providing water and the acquisition of any necessary permits or easements as follows a the city will levy taxes to retire any debt incurred by the city for these purposes from any combination levies allowed under the north dakota century part 2006   purchase of water the city may purchase water from another entity subject to the conditions as set forth in this section a the water needs of the city must exceed the amount of water which the citys supply and treatment system can efficiently deliver  b the purchase of additional water must be agreed to in a written agreement between the city and the entity providing the additional water  c the water owned by the city or which the city has the right to use shall be the first water used for city purposes and the secondary water used shall be the water purchased by the city from the other entity  d in the event of an emergency caused by the failure or problems to the citys supply and treatment system part 2006   voter approval any provision of or 403316 ndcc which may require voter approval of any provision of this chapter are rejected and the provisions of this chapter shall supercede any provision which may require voter approval part 2006   severability should any section provision or part of this chapter be adjudged invalid or unconstitutional such adjudication should not affect the validity of the ordinance codified in this chapter as a whole or any section provision or part thereof not adjudged invalid or unconstitutional part 2006   effective out herein the former pertained to similar subject matter and derived from    definitions in this chapter unless the context or subject matter otherwise requires merchandise does not include the sale of livestock or agricultural products for processing or the sale of living livestock transient merchant includes any person individual copartnership or corporation either as principal or agent who engages in does or transacts any temporary or transient business in the city and who does not intend to become or does not become a permanent merchant of the city the term transient merchant shall not apply to sales made to dealers by commercial travelers or selling agents in the usual course of business nor shall it apply to a person firm or corporation exhibiting goods for sale concurrent with and as an adjunct to a group display meeting convention or event held in or at a publiclyowned or operated building or facility or sales of merchandise damaged by smoke or fire or of bankrupt condition where such stocks have been acquired from merchants of the city thereof engaged in business  provided however no stocks of merchandise shall be augmented by new goods    license required it shall be unlawful for any person or for any agent servant or employee of any person or entity to engage in carry on or conduct the sale of merchandise as a transient merchant without first obtaining a license to do so    application any transient merchant desiring to engage in do or transact business or the sale of merchandise by auction or otherwise in the city of devils lake shall file an application for a license for that purpose with the city auditor which shall be in writing and include the following a applicants name present address present home address present business address and date of birth b applicants residence and business address for the prior twoyear period if different from the present residence and address c type of business in which applicant has been engaged in the previous two years d location of the business to be licensed e kind of business to be conducted f the dates and hours when sales will be conducted in the city of devils lake g an itemized list of merchandise to be offered for sale reciting as to each type a description thereof including serial number if any the owners actual cost thereof and a designation by number corresponding with the number to be affixed to each item by a tag which shall be kept fastened to the item at all times until sold h the location where the transient merchant will conduct business in the city i the name and address of each political subdivision where the applicant has submitted an applicant for a transient merchant license in the past six months    fee the application in be accompanied by a nonrefundable license fee which is required of all transient merchants for the transaction of such business within the city of devils lake as is contemplated in and provided by ndcc any subsequent amendments this fee is fixed at the sum of fifty dollars per day for each and every day during which any such transient merchant shall transact business in the city of devils lake or the sum of five hundred dollars for a permit for a period of ninety days    bond any person desiring to transact business within the city of devils lake as a transient merchant shall along with the application fee for a license include with the application in surety bond or deposit of cash in lieu thereof to the city auditor in the amount of five thousand dollars the surety of which shall be a surety company authorized to transact business in the state of north dakota the contents and surety therein shall be subject to the approval of the city auditor and be conditioned that the applicant will in all things conform to the laws relating to transient merchants and further conditioned upon full compliance with all material oral or written statements and representations made by the applicant the applicants agents representatives or auctioneers with reference to merchandise sold or offered for sale or faithful performance under all warranties made with reference thereto the bond shall not be revocable nor terminate prior to the passage of two years time after the expiration of the license issued pursuant thereto    applicants license by attorney general no transient merchants license shall be issued to any applicant unless the applicant provides written proof that such person has obtained a valid and current license as a transient merchant from the attorney general of the state of north dakota as required by of the north dakota century    location the holder of a transient merchant license shall conduct business in one location but may go to other locations upon invitation    exemption an organization which is a bona fide nonprofit veterans charitable educational religious fraternal civic and service club organization or other public spirited organization as defined by the provisions of of the north dakota century any bona fide school service club or youth organization is not required to have a transient merchant license in order to conduct sales which would otherwise require such a license under this chapter    sales in public facilities exempted the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to sales conducted in or at a publicly owned or operated building park or facilities as part of a civic event provided such sales are approved by the city commission    license display any transient merchant licensed hereunder shall prominently display the license at the licensed location    penalty any person who engages in business within the city of devils lake as a transient merchant without first obtaining a license to do so as herein provided shall be subject to a penalty of up to five hundred dollars each day a person conducts business in violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to be a separate offense and shall be punishable accordingly words and phrases have the meanings respectively ascribed herein alcoholic beverages means any liquid intended for drinking by humans which contains onehalf of one percent or more of alcohol by volume which is fit or intended for use for beverage purposes beer means any alcoholic beverages that is of the alcohol content provided by the laws of the state in defining the word beer food and beverage specialty license means a license which permits the sale of beer andor wine at retail subject to the following 1 beer and wine only 2 beer only habitual drunkard is a person who is habitually addicted to the use of any or all intoxicating liquors regularly becomes intoxicated or who by reason of habitual intemperance drinking of intoxicating liquor is at times dangerous to himself or herself or others or is incapable of managing himself or herself and his or her affairs 1 any person who has been incarcerated for the purpose of detoxification or any person who has been arrested for any offense against the peace while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a combination of such offenses more than five times in a twelvemonth period shall be deemed to be a habitual drunkard for the purpose of this chapter 2 it is not necessary that such person be intoxicated most of the time or have lost the will power to resist alcoholic drinks 3 for the purposes of this definition it is not necessary to prove the means of the intoxication is by drinking alcoholic beverages as defined herein but only that the person was intoxicated by alcohol introduced into the persons system in some form regardless of the intended use of the alcohol hotelmotel license means a special license that permits the sale of all alcoholic beverages on an onsale and offsale basis intoxicated person means a person who displays signs and symptoms commonly associated with over consumption of alcoholic beverages these signs and symptoms include but are not limited to any of the following strong odor of alcohol poor balance staggering swaying slurred speech loud or obnoxious behavior blood shot or watery eyes vomiting grogginess poor handeye coordination fighting behavior or any combination thereof licensed premises means that premises on which alcoholic beverages are normally sold or dispensed and shall be delineated by diagram or blueprint which shall be included with the license application or the license renewal application licensed premises includes all areas where alcoholic beverages are routinely stored displayed opened or mixed and all lounges bars and restaurants where alcoholic beverages are dispensed meeting rooms banquet rooms or other rooms not part of the licensed premises may be leased by groups or individuals for private events such as receptions banquets and similar events at which alcoholic beverages may be consumed provided that the licensee does not open mix or dispense alcoholic beverages in those areas not licensed licensee means the person to whom a license has been issued under the provisions of this chapter liquor means any alcoholic beverage other than beer lodge or club means any corporation or association organized for civic fraternal social or business purposes or for the promotion of sports which has at least two hundred members at the time a license is applied for pursuant to this chapter offsale means the sale of alcoholic beverages in original packages for consumption off or away from the premises where sold offsale is restricted to businesses with a class i ii iii iv or v license onsale means the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption only on the premises where sold packages and original package means any container or receptacle holding alcoholic beverages which is corked or sealed by the manufacturer and which cork or seal has not been removed or broken prior to the sale of such package to the purchaser person means persons partnerships other unincorporated associations and corporations sale means any transfer exchange or barter in any manner or by any means whatsoever for a consideration and includes all sales made by any person whether principal proprietor agent servant or employee sell at retail or sale basis which may be issued to steak seafood or similarly menued supper clubs having a seating capacity of one hundred or more seats arranged in supper club style ie adequate room to safely accommodate the number of tables required to have people seated two to eight persons to a table transfer means any assignment sale exchange or other conveyance of any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter a transfer shall be deemed to have occurred upon the assignment sale exchange or other conveyance of fifty percent or more of the interest in a licensee partnership or stock in a licensee conveyances 1 when an individual holding a license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter has become deceased the license may upon application of the personal representative of the decedent defined by the north dakota century or to a grandchild of the individual licensee if the grandchilds parents are deceased for purposes of this subsection only conveyance of shares of stock in a licensee corporation shall not be considered a transfer if the person seeking to convey shares of stock owns at least a majority of the outstanding shares of stock in said corporation  6 when a majority of the entire commission adopts a resolution and declares the conveyance not to be a transfer for the purposes of this chapter part 1988    applicability of chapterexceptions this chapter is declared to be an exercise of the police power directly affecting and designed to promote the peace safety good order health and wellbeing of the people of the city this chapter shall apply to all territory within the city and to such outlying contiguous territory without the corporate limits within which the city may exercise police jurisdiction as defined by law provided however that the following exceptions shall be noted to the applicability hereof a this chapter shall not apply to wines delivered to priests rabbis and ministers for sacramental use b this chapter shall not be construed to apply to the following articles when they are unfit for beverage purposes 1 denatured alcohol produced and used pursuant to acts of congress and the regulations thereunder  2 patent proprietary medical pharmaceutical antiseptic and toilet preparations  3 flavoring extracts syrups and food products  4 scientific chemical and industrial products nor to the manufacture or sale of said articles containing alcohol part 1988   licenserequired a a person may not sell at retail within the city limits of devils lake any alcoholic beverages without first having obtained a license therefor as herein provided this section does not apply to public carriers engaged in interstate commerce b a license may not be issued to any person engaged in business as the representative or agent of another a license may be issued only to the owner or owners of the business being conducted at the location sought to be licensed c the individual to be responsible for compliance with all city ordinances who is named in the license application must be the owner if the licensee is an individual a partner or manager if the licensee is a partnership or other unincorporated association and an officer of the corporation or manager if the licensee is a corporation part 1988   licenseterm a all licenses issued hereunder shall be for a period of not more than one year and shall expire on the transfer of an existing retail liquor and beer license permitting the retail sales of alcoholic beverages during the license year for the unexpired portion of such year for said license the proposed transferee for said license shall pay a transfer fee to the city in the amount of one hundred dollars for administrative processing purposes said license if allowed to be transferred shall then remain in full force and effect until the expiration of the term for which it was issued without payment of any additional fee by either party thereto  part 1988   classes of licenses fees and limitation of number issued a the board finds that in order to ensure compliance by all licensees with all applicable federal state and city laws ordinances and regulations and in order to adequately police all
