as the devils lake land subdivision regulations part 1994   purpose and intent a to insure the orderly development of the city and environ within one mile of the corporate limits  b to provide for a proper arrangement of streets in relation to other existing and planned streets for convenient access to the adjoining lands  c to provide for adequate and convenient open spaces for traffic utilities fire fighting equipment recre ation light and air  d to facilitate adequate provisions of transportation water sewerage schools parks and open space  e to avoid undue concentration of population and traffic  f to avoid development in unsuitable areas because of soil drainage elevation and other physical limitations  g to complement the zoning regulations for implementing the comprehensive plan to guide the future growth and development of the city  h to facilitate further subdivision of larger parcels into smaller parcels and lots i to meet the criteria set forth in all applicable ordinances including but not limited to the mailboxnewspaper box codified as of this code and the flood plain district codified as of this code part 2001  part 1994   adoption authority these regulations are adopted under the authority granted by chapters 4048 and 4050 of the north dakota century part 1994   jurisdiction these regulations shall apply to the use and enjoyment of all lands within the city and two miles outside of the city corporate limits as provided by of the north dakota century extraterritorial planning area and regulation of subdivisions apply not only to all property within the corporate limits of the city but shall extend a distance of two miles from the corporate limits of the city as provided in north dakota century 1 as amended  part 1994   compliance required any person firm or corporation dividing land in the city and its extraterritorial planning area shall prepare a plat of subdivision and shall comply with all applicable regulations codes ordinances and policies of the city and the laws and regulations of the state of north dakota part 1994   interpretation these regulations shall be held to be minimum requirements adopted for promotion of purposes cited in whenever the requirements of these regulations are at variance with the requirements of other lawfully adopted rules regulations ordinances deed restrictions or covenants the most restrictive shall govern unless otherwise specifically stated part 1994   severability if any part provision or portion of these regulations is adjudged invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction the remainder of this title shall not be affected thereby part 1994   comprehensive planobjectives these regulations are administered and enforced to implement the comprehensive plan of the city a document adopted by the board of city commissioners as a guide for the physical development of the city including the following objectives a to conserve and enhance the taxable value of land and buildings in the city and environ  b to encourage the most appropriate use of land in the city and environ  c to preserve and increase the amenities of the city and environ  d to protect residential commercial and manufacturing areas alike from harmful encroachment by incompatible uses  e to protect the character and maintain the stability of residential commercial and industrial areas and to promote orderly development  f to regulate and restrict the location and intensity of use of buildings and land for residential commercial industrial and other uses  g to separate and control unavoidable nuisanceproducing uses to minimize the adverse impacts on the surrounding areas or uses  h to minimize the expenditure of public funds costeffective alternatives for expansion of the city services  i to minimize business interruption  j to minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water mains sewer mains and streets part 1994   effective date these regulations shall be effective upon adoption by the board of city commissioners as provided by the north dakota century part 1994 rules and definitions rules of construction in construction of these regulations the rules and definitions contained in this section shall be observed and applied except when the context clearly indicates otherwise a words used in present tense shall include the future b words used in singular number shall include the plural number and the plural number the singular c shall is a mandatory word and not discretionary d may is a permissive word part 1994   definitions as used in this title alley means a public rightofway which affords only a secondary means of access to abutting property applicant means the owner of land to be subdivided or hisher representative block means a group of lots tracts or parcels of land bounded by streets parks railroad rightsofway shoreline of water ways lakes or the city corporate limits building means any structure designed or intended for shelter housing business office and accommodation of persons animals chattel or property building area means that portion of the lot that can be occupied by the principal building excluding the front rear and side yards building line means a line establishing the minimum distance that structures may be placed from lot lines or street rightsofway capital improvement program means a proposed schedule of future infrastructure including water sewer street curb gutter and sidewalk together with cost estimates and the anticipated means of financing each part channel means a natural or manmade water course conducting the flowing water city planning commission means a body of citizens appointed by the board of city commissioners under the authority of of the north dakota century review the planning issues prepare plans review the zoning requests amendments and conditional uses and make recommendations to the city commission for final decisions the city planning commission shall have the authority to review and approve all preliminary and final plats and replats within the city and in the extraterritorial planning area comprehensive plan means a guide for physical development of the city as provided by culdesac means a local street with one open end to traffic and the other end terminated by a vehicular turnaround the length of a culdesac shall not exceed five hundred feet dedication means deliberate appropriation of land by the owner to any public use developer means the owner of land to be subdivided or hisher representatives development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate including but not limited to the construction of buildings structures or accessory structures the construction of additions or alternations to buildings or structures ditching lagooning dredging filling grading paving excavation and drilling operations development plan means a document including maps and data for physical development of an area as provided by dwelling means any building or portion thereof used exclusively for human habitation including singlefamily and multiplefamily units but not including hotels or motels dwelling detached detached dwelling means a singlefamily residential unit surrounded by open space on the same lot dwelling multiplefamily multiplefamily dwelling means a single building or portion thereof containing two or more dwelling units dwelling singlefamily singlefamily dwelling means a building containing one dwelling unit only dwelling unit means one or more rooms designed for occupancy for one or more persons living as a house keeping unit easement means a right to use land for a specific purpose such right being held by someone other than the owner who holds the title to the land encroachment means any fill building structure or use including accessory uses projecting into the required yard areas or public and private property establishment means a place of business for processing production assembly sales service of goods and materials family means two or more persons related by blood marriage or adoption occupying a dwelling unit a family may include not more than two unrelated persons by blood marriage or adoption final plat means the map plan or record of a subdivision and any accompanying material prepared in conformance with these regulations floodplain means an area which may be covered by flood water including but not limited to regional floods floor area means the total square footage of floor space within the exterior walls of a building excluding garages and carports frontage means the front part of a lot abutting a public street frontage street means any street in which the development shall take place for access to abutting lots grade means the slope of a road street or lot defined in percentage improvements means street grading surfacing installation of sidewalks curb gutter water sanitary and storm sewer systems culverts bridges trees or other such installations as may be required by the city planning commission lot area means the area within the lot lines lot means a piece parcel lot or area of land of continuous assemblage established by survey plat or deed lot corner corner lot means a lot abutting two public streets at their intersection lot depth depth lot means the average horizontal distance between the front lot line and the rear lot line lot double frontage double frontage lot means a lot having frontage on two separately designated streets lot interior interior lot means a lot located in the interiors of a block and not a corner lot lot lines means the property lines bounding the lot lot of record means a lot which is a part of a subdivision which has been recorded in the office of ramsey county register of deeds or a parcel of land the deed to which has been recorded in the office of ramsey county register of deeds lot width means the horizontal distance between the side lot lines of a lot measured at the front building setback line major plat means a plat of a subdivision containing four or more lots minor plat means a plat of subdivision containing less than four lots nonresidential plat means a plat whose intended use is other than residential such as commercial or industrial person means any individual firm corporation partnership or legal entity planned development means a grouping of buildings and structures on a site of five or more acres in single ownership which is not limited by the yard or building height limitations but is based on a detailed development plan and recorded in the office of ramsey county register of deeds upon approval by the board of city commissioners preliminary plat means the preliminary plan of a subdivision and any accompanying material prepared in accordance with the requirements of these regulations premises means a lot together with all buildings and structures on it public roadway or public way means any recorded rightofway including alleys sidewalks streets roads highways viaducts tunnels bridges and public easements regional flood means a flood determined by the city state and federal authorities which is representative of large floods known to have occurred in ramsey county north dakota replat means a change in an approved or recorded plat requiring changes in street layout lot lines or blocks rightofway means a strip of land designated or dedicated for streets sidewalks railroad electric transmission line telephone and telegraph lines oil or gas pipeline sanitary and storm sewer or water systems sign means any emblem name identification description or illustration which is used for outdoor advertising having permanent location on the ground or attached to or painted on a building including bulletin boards billboards and poster boards flags but excluding real estate forsale signs political campaign signs public information and traffic signs story means that portion of a building between the surface of any floor and the surface of the next floor above it or if there is no floor above it then space between the floor and the ceiling above it a basement shall be counted as a story if more than onehalf of it is above grade street means any public way which affords traffic circulations and a principal means of access to abutting property streets include alleys highways roads viaducts tunnels bridges street arterial arterial street means public way which provide for movement of large volumes of traffic as designated by the city street collector collector street means a public way intended to carry traffic to and from minor streets and to and from the major streets as designated by the city street line means the outer boundary of any public rightofway street local local street means a public way intended for low volume of traffic which provides access to collector and arterial streets street major major street means a public way arterial or collector streets used primarily for carrying a large volume of traffic street minor minor street means a public way intended to provide pedestrian and vehicular access to the abutting properties structure means anything constructed or erected the use of which requires permanent location on the ground including advertising signs and billboards subdivider means any person group corporation entity or agency dividing or proposing to divide land so as to constitute a subdivision subdivision means the division of a tract or parcel of land into lots for the purpose whether immediate or future of sale or of building development and any plat or plan which includes the creation of any part of one or more streets public easement or other rightsofway whether public or private for access to or from such lots and the creation of new or enlarged parks playgrounds plazas or open spaces part 1994 special provisions land suitability no land shall be divided or subdivided for a use which is held unsuitable by the city for reasons of flooding potential soil limitations drainage or any other condition likely to be harmful to the health safety or welfare of the future residents or poses difficulty for the city a developer or subdivider may as a part or preapplication procedures request a determination of land suitability provided that he shall submit all necessary data and information to the city for such a determination part 1994   dedication of land for streets whenever a parcel of land to be subdivided as a subdivision contains a street or public way such street or public way shall be dedicated to the city at the location and details shown on the final plat part 1994 application procedure and review process preapplication procedure prior to preparing a preliminary plat the subdivider may consult with the code administrator and the city engineer concerning the regulations governing the division or subdivision of land in the city access to the city utilities services and conformance with the comprehensive plan specifically the areas for consultation shall include a feasibility of development related to the land suitability elements of the comprehensive plan efficient use of utilities and public services b review of the subdivision regulations for required improvements developers agreement and the bonding needs c responsibility of the city for extension of services acceptance of dedication for street rightsofway drainage courses and open spaces part 1994   preliminary platapplication the preliminary plat shall be prepared by a registered land surveyor and shall be submitted to the city engineer for review and approval by the city planning commission the preliminary plat shall cover the entire contiguous area owned or controlled by the subdivider if it is under forty acres even though only a small portion of it is proposed for the development at the time the subdivider may be required to submit a development plan if he owns or controls more than forty contiguous acres of land part 1994   preliminary platcontent the preliminary plat shall include the following requirements data and information a the preliminary plat drawn at a scale of not smaller than one inch equals one hundred feet  b name and location of the subdivision  c date graphic scale and north point  d boundary line of the proposed subdivision indicated by a solid heavy line accurately drawn to scale and showing distances and bearings  e total acreage within the subdivision  f location rightofway width and names of any existing or proposed streets including type and width of surfacing or public ways easement railroad utility rightsofway parks and other public open spaces permanent buildings or structures corporate boundaries and section lines within or adjacent to the subdivision  g location of existing property lines buildings drives streams water courses wooded areas and drainage ways  h existing water mains storm sewers sanitary sewers culverts bridges and other utility structures within the tracts indicating pipe size grades and location as obtained from public records  i existing zoning of the proposed subdivision and the zoning of the adjacent tracts of land  j boundary line of adjacent tracts of land or lots showing owners names  k contour at vertical intervals of not more than two feet  l location and dimension of any site to be reserved or dedicated for public uses including drainage ways parks and open spaces  m layout of the proposed streets alleys crosswalks and easements showing widths and street names  n layout number and dimensions of all lots and blocks  o parcels of land intended to be dedicated or reserved for public use or set aside for the use of property owners within the subdivision  p building setback lines showing dimensions  q a key map at a scale of one inch equals four hundred feet or less showing the boundary of the proposed subdivision and covering an area within one half mile around the subdivision part 1994   preliminary platsubmission requirements a the subdivider shall apply on appropriate forms provided by the city engineer to the city planning commission at least fifteen days prior to its regularlyscheduled meeting b the subdivider shall submit six prints of the preliminary plat to the city engineer at the time the application is made the plat shall comply with the provisions of these regulations the city engineer may refuse to accept the preliminary plat if he finds the plat in conflict with one or more provisions of these regulations fees charged for the filing of the subdivision plat shall be paid in full at the time of application in accordance with these regulations c the subdivider may submit any instrument whereby heshe proposes to regulate land use in the subdivision for protecting the proposed development d the subdivider shall provide other data related to drainage soil suitability financing of improvement and other related information which the city engineer or the code administrator request part 1994   development plan where a development plan is required for a tract of land the following shall be included in the plan a location of existing property lines buildings drives streams wooded areas and other significant natural features b general layout of proposed streets and location of blocks for designated uses c location of open spaces and facilities for public uses d existing drainage pattern based on the available topographic information from the us geological survey maps and other similar information e the development plan shall be drawn at a scale of one inch equaling four hundred feet f the city planning commission may require other information as a part of the development plan part 1994   preliminary platreview process a the city engineer shall retain one copy of the preliminary plat and submit copies with a request for comment within five days to the county health officer school district the utility companies heshe shall appoint a time for staff review to determine if all requirements of these regulations are met and the preliminary plat is consistent with the comprehensive plan as well as policies of public agencies and the private utility companies for lands within the extraterritorial planning area a representative of creel township be invited to the staff review meeting the public agency may include any of the city agencies as well as the concerned county or state agencies b if the city engineer finds the preliminary plat in substantial conformity with these regulations and the comprehensive plan heshe shall submit the preliminary plat together with the review comments of public agencies and private agencies to the city planning commission c the city planning commission shall review the preliminary plat and the comments of the public and private agencies upon which it may approve approve conditionally or deny the application and the preliminary plat the city planning commission may require additional information before it takes action the city planning commission shall cite the reasons for denying the application d the conditional approval of a preliminary plat shall clearly state the nature and extent of the conditions which shall be met before a final plat is submitted for review and approval tentative approval of a preliminary plat by the city planning commission is not an acceptance of a subdivision plat but is an expression of approval of a general plat as a guide to preparation of a subdivision for final plat review and approval e the city planning commission may require the subdivider to submit a revised preliminary plat before the subdivider proceeds with the preparation of the final plat f approval of the preliminary plat shall be effective for a period of twelve months within which a final plat shall be prepared if the final plat is not submitted within this time period the city planning commission may require the subdivider to resubmit the preliminary plat for review and approval part 1994   final platgenerally the final plat shall cover the area which is realistically designated for transfer or sale of lots part 1994   final platcontent the final plat shall conform to all provisions of these regulations and conditions set forth by the city planning commission a name of subdivision and date of tentative approval by the city planning commission  b location by section township and range or other legal description  c names of owners and surveyor or other professional person preparing the plat  d scale which shall be one inch equals one hundred feet or less  e date graphic scale and north point  f boundary line of subdivision based on an accurate traverse showing distances and bearings  g exact location width and name of all streets within and adjoining the subdivision and the exact location of all alleys and crosswalks  h true bearing and distances to the nearest established street lines or official monuments which shall be accurately described on the plat  i city township county or section lines accurately tied to the boundary lines of the subdivision by bearing and distance  j radii internal angles points of curvature tangent bearings and lengths of all arcs  k all easements for rightofway provided for public services and public utilities  l all lot number and lot lines with accurate dimensions in feet and hundredths  m accurate location of all monuments which shall be of material and size in accordance with the standards of the city and the state  n accurate outlines and legal descriptions of any areas not including streets alleys or public utility easements to be dedicated or reserved for public use  with the purposes indicated thereon  and of any area to be reserved by deed covenant for common use of all property owners  o building setback lines accurately shown with dimensions  p where required detailed engineering drawings crosssections or profiles of street utility lines catch basins or other installations of improvements as installed  q certification by registered surveyor to the effect that the plat represents a survey made by him and that the monuments shown thereon exist as located and that all dimensional and geodetic details are correct  r notarized certification by the owners of the land of the adoption of the plat and the dedication of sewers water distribution lines and other improvements and of streets and other public areas  s proper form for the approval by the city planning commission and for acceptance of plat and amendment of master street plan by the board of city commissioners part 1994   final platsubmission requirements the subdivider shall apply on appropriate forms to the city planning commission for approval of the final plat if heshe holds a valid approval of the preliminary plat a the subdivider shall submit the final plat plan in two plastic or cloth tracings and five prints to the city engineer at least two weeks before the regularlyscheduled meeting of the city planning commission b the final plat shall comply with all provisions of these regulations and conditions and requirements set forth as a part of review and approval of the preliminary plat all filing fees shall be paid to the city at the time of filing the final plat for approval in accordance with the provisions of c the city engineer may require the subdivider to submit detailed drawings for grading of the lots blocks streets detailed drawings for pavement curb gutter and sidewalk drawings for installation of water sanitary and storm sewer facilities part 1994   final platreview process a the city engineer shall review the final plat with other city agencies and other agencies including the county health officer school district and the utility companies as prescribed in these regulations b if the city engineer finds the final plat in conformance with the requirements stipulated for approval of the preliminary plat heshe shall submit the final plat to the city planning commission with the review comments of the public and private agencies the city engineer shall review the detailed drawings and specifications for the required improvements c for subdivisions outside of the city corporate limits a print of the final plat shall be submitted to the ramsey county planning commission the approval of the county planning commission is necessary for all plats outside of the city d upon receipt of the final plat by the city engineer the secretary of the city planning commission shall give notice of public hearing on the proposed subdivision by date time and place of hearing in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least five days prior to the date of hearing e the subdivider shall furnish the name and address of the owner of the land or hisher agent at the time of application who should be notified of the public hearing date time and place by registered mail at least five days before the hearing f the city engineer shall prepare an estimate of the cost of providing the required improvements based on the city design standards for street curb gutter sidewalk sanitary sewer storm sewer and water lines the city engineer shall make a determination for adequacy of posted deposit or surety bond for the required improvements g the city planning commission after the public hearing shall determine that 1 the requirements of these regulations for preparation of a plat have been met  2 the necessary fees have been collected or paid  3 all taxes and assessments on the property have been paid evidenced by a certificate or receipt  4 detailed design and specifications for improvements have been approved by the city engineer  5 other requirements by the city planning commission have been met h if all conditions and requirements have been met the city planning commission shall approve the final plat by entering the signature of the secretary and chairman of the city planning commission on the original the city planning commission shall act on the request for approval of the final plat within thirty days failure to act within such period shall be deemed as approval of the subdivision if an extension of time is not negotiated part 1994   amendment of comprehensive plan upon final approval of a subdivision involving the creation of new streets the widening decreasing or vacation of existing streets or alleys or the creation enlargement or decrease of other lands devoted to public use the city planning commission shall at the time and without further public hearing approve such change in streets alleys or public lands as an amendment to the comprehensive plan the city planning commission shall transmit notice of such action to the board of city commissioners together with appropriate recommendations concerning the acceptance of the dedicated streets and alleys or the vacation thereof and of the acceptance of other dedicated lands in the case of streets alleys and public lands outside of the city corporate limits notice of action of the city planning commission and appropriate recommendations shall be forwarded to the board of county commissioners part 1994   filing of subdivision plat the subdivider upon approval of the final plat shall file the plat with the register of deeds of ramsey county sale of any lot prior to filing of the final plat is in violation of these regulations part 1994 design standards conformance with provisions required the subdivider shall prepare the preliminary and final plat in conformance with the standard set forth herein part 1994   street design a the arrangement character classification extent width grade and location of all streets shall conform to the comprehensive plan and shall be designed in relation to existing and planned streets topographic conditions existing natural features public convenience and safety and the proposed uses of land served by such streets and to the most advantageous development of adjoining uses b where it is not shown on the comprehensive plan the arrangement of streets in a subdivision shall either provide for the continuation or appropriate projection of existing collector or arterial streets in surrounding areas or conform to a plan for the neighborhood approved by the city planning commission to meet a particular situation where topographic or other physical conditions make conformance to the existing street pattern impractical c local streets shall be laid out so as to discourage d where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed arterial street or highway the city planning commission may require service streets reverse frontage lots with screen planting in a reservation strip along the rear property line deep lots with rear service alleys abutting the primary street or highway or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and for separation of local traffic e where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad rightofway or limited access highway rightofway the city planning commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of the rightofway at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land such distances shall be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations f reserve strips in private ownership controlling access to streets are prohibited g street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred fifty feet shall be avoided h a tangent at least one hundred feet long shall be introduced between reverse curves on major and collector streets i when connecting street lines deflect from each other at any one point by more than ten degrees they shall be connected by a curve with a radius adequate to insure a sight distance of not less than four hundred feet for local and collector streets and of such greater radii as the city planning commission shall determine for special cases j streets shall be laid out so as to intersect as nearly as possible at right angles and no street shall intersect any other street at less than eighty degrees k curb radii on all block corners shall be ten feet and a fivefoot radius shall be used at intersections of streets and alleys l urban street rightsofway shall be as shown on the comprehensive plan where not shown on the plan shall be not less than the following 1 primary arterial streets one hundred feet  2 secondary arterial streets one hundred feet  3 collector streets eighty feet  4 local streets sixty feet  5 culdesac one hundred ten feet in diameter for a turnaround  6 alleys residential district sixteen feet  7 sidewalks four feet  8 graded widths of rural roadways shall be as shown on the comprehensive plan but shall be not less than the following a primary arterial streets fortyeight feet b secondary arterial streets fortyfour feet c collector streets forty feet d local streets thirtytwo feet e culdesac eightyfive feet in diameter for a turnaround f alleys sixteen feet g sidewalks four feet m half streets are prohibited except where essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision and in conformity with the other requirements of these regulations and where the city planning commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is subdivided wherever an existing half street is adjacent to a tract to be subdivided the other half of the street shall be platted within such tract n culdesacs shall not be longer than five hundred feet o general considerations for intersection design are that 1 intersections of more than two streets at a point shall not be permitted 2 alleys shall be discouraged in residential districts but may be provided in commercial and industrial districts p deadend streets without a suitable turnaround are prohibited part 1994   block design the length width and shape of blocks shall be suited to the planned use of land zoning requirements needs for convenient access control of safety of street traffic and the topographic conditions a residential block length shall not exceed nine hundred feet the length of blocks is considered to be the distance from one street centerline to opposite street centerline and is measured back lot lines or center of the block b pedestrian crosswalks not less than ten feet wide may be required in blocks longer than six hundred feet where the crosswalks are deemed by the city planning commission to be essential to provide circulation or access to schools playgrounds shopping centers transportation or other community facilities c the width of the blocks shall generally be sufficient to allow two tiers of lots and shall be at least two hundred feet wide d blocks intended for commercial and industrial use shall be specifically designated for such purposes with adequate space set aside for offstreet parking and delivery facilities the city planning commission may require service drives or frontage roads along arterial and collector streets for commerce and industry e where frontage is on an arterial street the long dimension of the block should front it part 1994   lot design a the shape size and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision the lots should be designed to provide an aesthetically pleasing building site for residential low density a northsouth lot orientation is encouraged residential lot dimension within the city corporate limits shall be 1 minimum width at building line fifty feet  2 minimum depth one hundred feet  3 minimum lot area seven thousand square feet for nonresidential lots the provisions of appropriate zoning districts stipulated in title 17 of this code shall apply b residential lot dimensions within the extraterritorial planning area shall be 1 minimum width at building line one hundred feet  2 minimum depth two hundred feet  3 minimum lot area twenty thousand square feet c residential lots abutting arterial and collector streets shall have extra depth of at least twenty feet to allow for proper setbacks d all lots shall front a public street e side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles f residential corner lots shall have an extra width of ten feet to permit adequate building setbacks from the side streets g in case a parcel is subdivided into smaller parcels such parcels shall be arranged as to allow the resubdivision of any such parcels into normal lots in accordance with these regulations h lot lines shall follow the city corporate limits i double frontage lots shall be avoided except where essential to provide separation of development from arterial streets j depth and width of lots reserved or laid out for commercial or industrial uses shall be adequate to provide for offstreet parking and service facilities required by the type of use and development and the provisions of the appropriate zoning district part 1994   street names a the city planning commission may disapprove the name of any street shown on the plat which has already been used elsewhere in the area or because of similarity that may cause confusion b where a street maintains the same general direction except for curvilinear changes for a short distance the same name shall continue for the entire length of the street c a name assigned to a street which is not presently a shall be continued for the separate part of a d street designation shall be limited to the following conditions 1 boulevard meaning a divided pavement  2 circle or court meaning a culdesac or circle  3 drive meaning a   4 lane meaning a street one block long part 1994   utility easements a easements across lots or along rear or side lot lines shall be provided for utilities where necessary and shall be at least five feet wide on each side of the lot line and shall be designated as utility easements b all lots shall be served by underground electric cable television and telephone lines unless waived by the city planning commission due to topographic conditions or excessive costs c all utility lines for electric power cable television and telephone service carried overhead shall be placed in utility easement d utility lines installed in the utility easement shall not be closer than one foot to the property line or three feet to any monument the utility easement grade shall be set by the city engineer part 1994   grading and drainage a when required the subdivider shall provide a detailed grading and drainage plan showing the grades of streets and drainage improvements b the drainage shall not discharge into any sanitary sewer facility c when required the subdivider shall provide suitable drainage facilities for any surface runoff affecting the subdivision the drainage facilities shall be located in street rightofway or in drainage easements d the grading and drainage system shall be approved by the city engineer e grading established in any subdivision shall not be changed without approval of the city engineer f street grades wherever feasible shall not exceed the following with due allowance for reasonable vertical curves 1 arterial streets primary and secondary four percent  2 collector streets five percent  3 local streets six percent g no street grade shall be less than onehalf of one percent h flat grades are preferred extending fifty to one hundred feet from an intersection but in no case shall grades exceed four percent for a distance of at least fifty feet from an intersection part 1994   drainage way easement where a subdivision is traversed by a water course or drainage way an adequate drainage way easement shall be provided the location width alignment and grading of such easement shall be set by the city engineer to accommodate the anticipated discharge from the property being subdivided and also the anticipated runoff from the adjoining properties part 1994   public use dedication a where a park playground school or other site for public use shown on the comprehensive plan is located in whole or in part in the applicants subdivision the city planning commission may require the dedication or reservation of such area within the subdivision b where deemed essential by the city planning commission upon consideration of the type of development proposed in the subdivision and especially in largescale developments not anticipated in the comprehensive plan the city planning commission may request the dedication or reservation of such other areas or sites of a character extent or location suitable to the needs created by the development for schools parks and other neighborhood facilities c when required all subdivisions shall be assessed an equitable amount in dollars andor land to implement the public sites and open space segments of the comprehensive plan the form and amount of assessment shall be fixed by the city planning commission at the meeting when the preliminary plat is reviewed part 1994   tree planting the planting of trees of an appropriate species and at appropriate locations may be required by the city planning commission in accordance with the standards established by the shade tree committee master plan part 1994   street lights street lights and their location shall be in accordance with the minimum design standards established by the city engineer part 1994 required improvements generally before installation of improvements in any subdivision the city engineer shall make a determination for improvements required based on a schedule of improvements including the standards and class of construction part 1994   completion assurance to cover the cost of improvements as determined by the city engineer the subdivider may either provide a certified check for twentyfive percent of the cost or post a bond or submit a letter of credit from an acceptable financial institution in an amount sufficient to construct such improvements the form and surety of the bond shall be approved by the city attorney part 1994   survey monuments the subdivider shall install survey monuments in all lots and block corners in the subdivision in accordance with the requirements of the city and state of north dakota part 1994   public water a water mains shall be installed so as to provide individual service to each lot within the subdivision b water mains shall extend to the boundary of the subdivision except where in the opinion of the city engineer it is deemed impractical c a rural water supply shall comply with the requirements of ramsey county and state of north dakota part 1994   sanitary sewer a all subdivisions shall be provided with sanitary sewers to each lot b sanitary sewer shall be extended to the boundary of the subdivision except where in the opinion of the city engineer it is deemed impractical part 1994   storm sewer the storm sewer drainage facilities shall be installed in accordance with the plans and specifications approved by the city engineer part 1994   grading and surfacing the full width of all rightsofway shall be graded and all streets shall be paved in accordance with the city street classification and pavement standards part 1994   curbs gutters and sidewalks concrete curbs and gutters shall be installed in all subdivisions in accordance with the city standards where the city requires construction of a sidewalk it shall be in accordance with the design standards established by the city engineer part 1994   installation of improvements a construction of all improvements is contingent on approval by the city engineer the subdivider shall be responsible for furnishing the necessary data required for such approval b at the time the plans profiles and specifications are submitted for review the city engineer shall prepare an estimate for cost for all improvement all work done by the city engineer in connection with checking computing and review of plans for improvement and in connection with field inspection of the construction thereof shall be charged to the deposit if during the progress of the work it appears that the cost will exceed the amount so deposited the city engineer shall notify the subdivider of this fact and shall do no further work in connection with the review of field inspection until the subdivider has deposited the additional amount of money necessary to cover the cost of the work c upon completion of the work of checking plans and inspecting the construction of improvements the city engineer shall forward to the city auditor a statement of the amount of the engineering and inspection costs to be charged against the deposit made by the subdivider the city auditor shall thereupon refund to the subdivider any unexpected balance of the deposit if the engineering and inspection charges shall for any reason exceed the amount of the deposit the city auditor shall collect the balance due and issue a statement that the charges have been paid part 1994   certification of final approval at the time of filing an application for installation of improvements the subdivider shall submit a a certificate signed by the city engineer that plans specifications and profiles for the improvements have been filed with and approved by himher b a certificate signed by the city auditor that a certified check or satisfactory surety bond or a letter of credit from an acceptable financial institution has been posted for completion of improvements part 1994 administration and enforcement organization administration of these regulations is vested in three offices of the city a the office of the code administrator  b the office of the city engineer  c the city planning commission part 1994   office of the code administrator the code administrator is a duly appointed city official authorized by the board of city commissioners and is responsible to administer zoning regulations subdivision regulations building code and housing code and to assist and make recommendations to the city planning commission and to the board of city commissioners on any matter to planning for and development of the city a duties and responsibilities the code administrator shall be specifically responsible for interpretation and enforcement of these regulations including assisting the city engineer in facilitating the review and approval of the plat 1 receive file and forward to the city planning commission all applications for preliminary and final plats and the supporting documents  2 forward all recommendations of the city planning commission to the board of city commissioners for final action  3 notify in writing the property owner or user upon finding violation of these regulations and cite the nature of violation clearly and require compliance within a reasonable time if the notification is not replied to or steps are not taken to correct the violations within thirty days the code administrator shall make a report of the findings to the city attorney and the board of city commissioners b interpretation of regulations all questions of interpretation of these regulations shall be first presented to the code administrator and that such questions shall be presented to the city planning commission only on appeal from the decision of the code administrator and that the recourse from the city planning commission shall be made to the board of city commissioners part 1994   office of the city engineer the city engineer is a duly appointed city official authorized by the board of city commissioners and is responsible for review and coordination of the review and approval process for the preliminary and final plats duties and responsibilities the city engineer shall be specifically responsible for the design of engineering standards for the city improvement programs and coordination with the code administrator to assure compliance a review the plans and specifications provided by the subdivider and make recommendations to the city planning commission  b coordinate the review process of the preliminary and final plats among the city county state agencies and utility companies  c prepare cost estimate for all improvement and coordinate the financing mechanism with the city auditor  d design and prepare the appropriate utility plans for improvements of the subdivisions the cost of which shall be born by the subdivider  e conduct inspection of the subdivision to assure compliance with the terms and conditions of subdivision approval part 1994   the city planning commission authority the city planning commission a citizen body nominated by the mayor and confirmed by the board of city commissioners is vested with authority and jurisdiction to review planning annexation zoning subdivision plat approval and city development matters and make recommendation to the board of city commissioners a the city planning commission shall consist of no more than ten members with two members who reside outside of the city corporate limits but within the extraterritorial zoning area and to be appointed by the ramsey county board of commissioners five citizen members are nominated by the mayor and approved by the board of city commissioners the other three voting members shall consist of the mayor city attorney and the city engineer devils lake municipal  the term of office for members representing the city shall be three years and overlapping which may be reviewed by the board of city commissioners the term of office for members appointed by the county one shall be for five years and one for three years b duties and responsibilities 1 to hear review and act on all applications for preliminary and final plats of subdivisions  2 to hear and act on all other matters referred to by the board of city commissioners  3 to study examine and make recommendations to the board of city commissioners regarding comprehensive planning for the future development of devils lake  4 to hear and decide all appeals forwarded by the code administrator related to the subdivision regulations c officers the city planning commission shall elect its own officers according to its bylaws and may establish rules and procedures for all cases before it the code administrator may serve as nonvoting secretary d notice of hearings the city planning commission shall fix a reasonable date for hearing of applications for preliminary and final plats and other matters before it and give public notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the city at least one week prior to the hearing the notices shall state the purpose of the hearing and that the applications and supporting documents for preliminary and final plats are available for public inspection in the office of the city engineer during the normal working hours e meetings meetings of the city planning commission shall be held at the call of the chairperson and at such other times as the city planning commission may determine all meetings shall be open to the public and any person may testify for or against an application for preliminary or final plat approval part 1994 variances procedure a upon application by the subdivider and where it can be shown that strict compliance with the requirements of these regulations would result in extraordinary hardship to the subdivider because of unusual topography or other such conditions thus retarding the achievement of the objective of these regulations the city planning commission may vary modify or waive requirements so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured provided that the variance modification or waiver will not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of these regulations or of the comprehensive plan b in no case shall any variance modification or waiver be more than a minimum of the requirements and in no case shall it have the effect of reducing the traffic capacity of any major or secondary streets and in no case shall it be in conflict with existing zoning regulations c in granting variances modifications or waivers the city planning commission may require any condition that will secure substantially the objectives of these regulations and the comprehensive plan part 1994 fees fees in order to cover the costs of advertising holding public hearings and other expenses incidental to the review and approval of a subdivision the subdivider shall pay a fee at the time of application for tentative approval of a preliminary plat the fee will be based upon the square footage of the land to be subdivided if the subdivider fails to submit a final plat within twelve months after receiving tentative approval of a preliminary plat it may be necessary to resubmit a preliminary plat for approval a the fees for approval of a subdivision shall be charged and collected as established by resolution of the board of city commissioners and revised as it may see fit b all fees collected for the approval of subdivision shall be credited to the general fund of the city c all fees established by this chapter are in addition to any sums paid to cover the costs of review of improvement plans and field inspection of construction required under the provisions of these regulations part 1994 violations and penalties violationspenalties any owner or the agent of any owner or land located within the territory of a subdivision that is subject to the approval of the city planning commission who transfers sells agrees to sell or negotiates to sell any land by reference to or exhibition of a plat of a subdivision or by any use thereof before the plat has been approved by the planning commission and recorded as approved in the office of the county register of deeds shall forfeit and pay a penalty of one hundred dollars for each lot or parcel transferred or sold or agreed or negotiated to be sold the description of the lot or parcel by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling of transferring shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties or from the remedies provided in this chapter the governing jurisdiction may enjoin the transfer sale or agreement by an action for injunction or it may recover the penalty by civil action part 1994 title 17  zoning general provisions   title for citation these regulations shall be known cited and referred to as the devils lake zoning regulations part 1994   purpose and intent a to promote public health safety morals comfort convenience prosperity and general welfare of the city and environs  b to lessen congestion in the streets  c to secure safety from fire panic noxious fumes and other dangers  d to promote adequate light air privacy and convenience of access to property  e to prevent the overcrowding of land  f to avoid undue concentration of population  g to facilitate the adequate provisions of transportation water sewerage schools parks and other public facilities  h to promote orderly development of land and water resources and to prevent conflict among land uses and structures part 1994   adoption authority these regulations are adopted under the authority granted by of the north dakota century part 1994   jurisdiction these regulations shall apply to the use and enjoyment of all lands within the city and two miles outside of the corporate limits of the city as provided by of the north dakota century city zoning regulations apply to not only all property within the corporate limits of the city but shall extend a distance of two miles from the corporate limits of the city as provided in north dakota century 1 as amended  part 1994   interpretation of provisions these regulations shall be held to be minimum requirements adopted for promotion of purposes cited in whenever the requirements of these regulations are at variance with the requirements of other lawfully adopted rules regulations ordinances deed restrictions or covenants the most restrictive shall govern unless otherwise specifically stated part 1994   severability if any part provision or portion of these regulations is adjudged invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction the remainder of this title shall not be affected thereby part 1994   comprehensive planobjectives these regulations are administered and enforced to implement the comprehensive plan of the city a document adopted by the board of city commissioners as a guide for the physical development of the city including the following objectives a to conserve and enhance the taxable value of land and buildings in the city and environ  b to encourage the most appropriate use of land in the city and environ  c to preserve and increase the amenities of the city and environ  d to protect residential commercial and manufacturing areas alike from harmful encroachment by incompatible uses  e to protect the character and maintain the stability of residential commercial and industrial areas and to promote orderly development of such areas  f to regulate and restrict the location and intensity of use of buildings and land for residential commercial industrial and other uses  g to separate and control unavoidable nuisance producing uses to minimize the adverse impacts on the surrounding areas or uses  h to minimize the expenditure of public funds costeffective alternatives for expansion of the city services  i to minimize business interruption  j to minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water mains sewer mains and streets part 1994   effective date these regulations shall be effective upon adoption by the board of city commissioners as provided by the north dakota century part 1994 rules and definitions   rules of construction in construction of these regulations the rules and definitions contained in this chapter shall be observed and applied except when the context clearly indicates otherwise a words used in present tense shall include the future b words used in singular number shall include the plural number and the plural the singular c shall is a mandatory word and not discretionary d may is a permissive word part 1994   definitions accessory building and uses means a subordinate building or portion of the main building the use of which is clearly incidental to and serves exclusively the principal building or principal use the accessory building or use shall be located on the same zoning lot and it is established to contribute to the comfort convenience or necessity of occupants of the principal building or principal use accessory dwelling unit means an auxiliary or subordinate dwelling unit on the same lotparcel or within an existing detached single family structure the unit includes its own independent living provisions for sleeping cooking and sanitation designed for residential occupancy independent of the primary dwelling unit airport means any area designated for the landing and takeoff of aircraft and any appurtenant areas which are used or intended for use for airport buildings and structures including runways taxi ways aircraft storage and tie down areas hangars and other related facilities and open spaces alley means a public rightofway which affords only a secondary means of access to abutting property animal confinement operation means an agricultural operation in which all animals are kept and raised within a completely enclosed structure animal rescue operation means any facility used to house and distribute for adoption as pets any stray homeless abandoned or unwanted animals operated or maintained by a public body an established humane society animal welfare society society for the prevention of cruelty to animals or other nonprofit organizations or by a person or persons devoted to the welfare protection and humane treatment of animals apartment means a room or suite of rooms in a multiplefamily dwelling used or designed for human occupancy basement means a story partly underground with more than onehalf of its height below grade a basement is not included in computing the number of stories for the purpose of measuring the building height unless more than onehalf of its height is above grade bed and breakfast means any place of temporary lodging that provides more than four rooms for rent and is the owners personal residence board of adjustment means the body appointed by the board of city commissioners to hear and decide appeals where it is alleged errors or inequities in the literal administration or enforcement of these regulations exist boarding house means any dwelling in which unrelated persons are housed for rent with or without meals building means any structure designed or intended for shelter housing business office and accommodation of persons animals chattels or property building area means that portion of the zoning lot that can be occupied by the principal use excluding the front rear and side yards building height means vertical distance from the grade to the highest point to the roof building line means a line establishing the minimum distance that structure may be placed from the lot lines or street rightofway for the purposes of these regulations the building line is the same as setback line building principal principal building means a building in which the principal use of the lot is conducted including singlefamily and multifamily dwellings and offices shops stores and other uses campground means any parcel of land containing three or more lots intended for occupancy by travel trailers or tents central area means that part of the city bounded by sixth street sixth avenue and the burlington northern railroad rightofway channel means a natural or manmade water course for conducting the flowing water city planning commission means a body of citizens appointed by the board of city commissioners under the authority of of the north dakota century review the planning issues prepare plans review the zoning requests amendments and conditional uses and make recommendations to the city commission for final decisions comprehensive plan means a guide for physical development of the city as provided by conditional use means use for a special nature not automatically permitted in a zoning district and which requires review and approval of the board of city commissioners after public hearing conforming building or structure means a building or structure which complies with all requirements of these regulations and other regulations adopted by the city development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate including but not limited to the construction of buildings structures or accessory structures the construction of additions or alterations to buildings or structures ditching lagooning dredging filling grading paving excavation and drilling operations development plan means a document including maps and data for physical development of an area as provided by district means a section or sections of the city for which regulations governing the use of building and premises the building height size of yards lot area lot width and the intensity of use are uniform dwelling means any building or portion thereof used exclusively for human habitation including singlefamily and multiplefamily units but not including hotels or motels dwelling detached detached dwelling means a singlefamily residential unit surrounded by open space on the same lot dwelling multiplefamily multiplefamily dwelling means a single building or portion thereof containing two or more dwelling units dwellingsingle family singlefamily dwelling means a building containing only one dwelling unit designed to be located on a permanent foundation as defined in this section and if site built constructed in accordance with the provision of the applicable city codes governing construction  or if manufactured offsite constructed in accordance with either the city codes governing construction or the hud manufactured home construction and safety standards 24 cfr 3280 all singlefamily dwellings shall be considered and taxed as real property as provided by law all singlefamily dwellings shall have minimum overall front width of twentyfour feet minimum overall depth of twenty feet and minimum main floor living space square footage of nine hundred square feet and a minimum ceiling height of seven feet dwelling twofamily twofamily dwelling means a building containing two dwelling units only dwelling unit means one or more rooms designed for occupancy for one or more persons living as a housekeeping unit efficiency unit means a dwelling containing one principal room in a dwelling unit for human occupancy excluding bathroom kitchen hallway and closets emergency medical air transport services means a service in conjunction with a hospital andor clinic used to transport patients by helicopter in need of emergency medical care at a medical facility either in devils lake or other medical facilities throughout the region encroachment means any fill building structure or use including accessory uses projecting into the required yard areas or public and private property establishment means a place of business for processing production assembly sales service of goods and materials family means two or more persons related by blood marriage adoption or child foster care occupying a dwelling unit a family may include not more than two unrelated persons by blood marriage or adoption feed lot means a parcel of land which contains a commercial operation for feeding and raising animals that are provided feed with little or no vegetation for forage andor grazing floodplain means an area which may be covered by flood water including but not limited to regional floods floor area means the total square footage of floor space within the exterior walls of a building excluding garages and car ports frontage means the front part of a lot abutting a public street garage private private garage means an accessory building or portion of a principal building designed and used for the storage of not more than four vehicles owned and used by the occupant of the building to which it is accessory garage public public garage means a building or portion thereof designed and used for repair maintenance sale service and storage of motor vehicles garage storage storage garage means a building or portion thereof designed and used exclusively for accommodating more than four motor vehicles grade means the land elevation at the horizontal intersection of the ground and the building home occupation means any occupation carried on in a dwelling unit by a member or members of the family and which meets these requirements 1 the occupation is conducted within the principal building or an accessory building  such occupations operated in an accessory building shall be limited to activities that do not generate objectionable noise dust or fumes operations such as body shops and auto repair shall not be permitted all home occupancy activities shall be conducted inside the home or accessory building and all supplies and materials shall be stored indoors  2 that the occupation is incidental and secondary to the use of the dwelling unit  3 that only the members of the immediate family residing on the premises may be employed unless authorized by the board of adjustment by a variance  4 that no stockintrade is kept or commodities sold other than those produced on the premises unless authorized by the board of adjustment  5 that samples may be kept but not sold on the premises  6 that no more than twentyfive percent of the floor area of the dwelling is devoted to such home occupation  7 that no sign or display other than a name plate not more than two square feet in area shall be used outside of the premises hotel or motel means a building in which lodging accommodations with or without meals are provided for compensation hotel apartment apartment hotel means a building in which some of the accommodations are dwelling units or are occupied by permanent residents institution means building or buildings occupied by a nonprofit private corporation or a public body for public use junk or salvage yard means an open area where waste or scrap material including parts of used motor vehicles appliances and farm implements are bought sold exchanged stored baled parked disassembled or handled kennel animal animal kennel means any premises where dogs cats and other household pets are boarded bred and maintained for compensation lodging house means a residential building or or meals lot means a piece parcel lot or area of land of continuous assemblage established by survey plat or deed lot area means the area within the lot lines lot corner corner lot means a lot abutting two public streets at their intersection lot depth means the average horizontal distance between the front lot line and the rear lot line lot double frontage double frontage lot means a lot having frontage on two separately designated streets lot interior interior lot means a lot located in the interior of a block and not a corner lot lot lines means the property lines bounding the lot lot of record means a lot which is a part of subdivision which has been recorded in the office of ramsey county register of deeds or a parcel of land the deed to which has been recorded in the office of ramsey county register of deeds lot width means the horizontal distance between the side lot lines of a lot measured at the front building setback line lot zoning zoning lot means a single lot parcel tract of land located within a single block developed or to be developed as a single unit manufactured home means a factorybuilt structure which is to be used as a place for human habitation which is not constructed with or equipped with a permanent hitch or other device allowing it to be moved other than to a permanent site which does not have permanently attached to its body or frame any wheels or axles and which bears a label certifying that it was built in compliance with the manufactured home construction and safety standards act 1974 24 cfr 3280 which became effective  promulgated by the united states department of housing and urban development medical marijuana dispensary means a facility that has been approved by the north dakota state health department as per ndcc and of the north dakota administrative rules to house dispense and sell approved marijuana products for medical purposes medical marijuana manufacturing means the process of preparing legal medical marijuana products as per ndcc and of the north dakota administrative rules for distribution and sale at approved medical marijuana dispensaries mobile home means a transportable factorybuilt home designed to be used as a yearround residential dwelling and built prior to enactment of the federal manufactured home constructed and safety standards act of 1974 24 cfr 3280 which became effective  a mobile or portable structure constructed to be towable on its chassis connected to utilities and used for yearround living it can consist of one or more units that can be telescoped when towed or two or more units separately towable but designed to be joined into one integral unit mobile home lot means a lot or parcel of land platted or planned to accommodate a mobile home mobile home park means a parcel of land for which a detailed plan indicating the location of lots blocks streets neighborhood facilities and parks and playgrounds exists nonconforming building means any building which does not comply with any or all of these regulations nonconforming use means any principal use of land or building which does not comply with any or all of these regulations nursing home or convalescent home means a home for the aged or infirm in which unrelated persons are accommodated for compensation outdoor storage means the keeping of vehicles with current license and registration recreational vehicles boats atvs snowmobiles trailers equipment and storage containers for an extended period of time without usage outside of a completely enclosed building storage containers shall comply with of the zoning regulations outdoor storage does not pertain to the lawful display of retail goods and equipment for sale on commercially zoned properties outdoor storage of junk andor rubbish shall not be allowed and shall be governed by title 8 of the municipal code permanent foundation means a foundation designed and placed in compliance with the north dakota state building adopted by the city of devils lake person means any individual firm corporation partnership or legal entity planned development means a grouping of buildings and structures on a site of five or more acres in single ownership which is not limited by the yard or building height limitations but is based on a detailed development plan and recorded in the office of ramsey county register of deeds upon approval by the board of city commissioners premises means a lot together with all buildings and structures on it public roadway or public way means any dedicated and recorded rightofway including alleys sidewalks streets roads or highways recreational vehicle means a travel trailer regional flood means a flood determined by the city state and federal authorities which is representative of large floods known to have occurred in ramsey county north dakota service station means any building or premises where automotive fuels automotive related services lubricants parts and supplies are made available to the motorist sign means any emblem name identification description or illustration which is used for outdoor advertising having permanent location on the ground or attached to or painted on a building including bulletin boards billboards and poster boards flags but excluding real estate forsale signs political campaign signs public information and traffic signs site plan means a detailed plan for making improvements to parcels of land for the purpose of building and development as provided in special use means use of a special nature not automatically permitted in a district and not listed among the conditional uses approval of any special use requires the review and approval of the board of adjustment story means that portion of a building between the surface of any floor and the surface of the next floor above it or if there is no floor above it then space between the floor and the ceiling above it a basement shall be counted as a story if more than onehalf of it is above grade story half half story means that part of a building between the eaves and the ridge line of pitched roofs not for human occupancy unless approved by the board of adjustment street means any public way which affords traffic circulations and a principal means of access to abutting property street line means the outer boundary of any public rightofway structural alterations means any change in the supporting elements of a building including bearing walls partitions columns beams girders roofs and exterior walls structure means anything constructed or erected the use of which require permanent location on the ground including advertising signs and billboards tavern means any place in which alcoholic beverages are sold primarily for consumption on the premises whereas a liquor store is a place where alcoholic beverages are sold exclusively for consumption off the premises tent means a collapsible shelter of canvas or other fabric stretched and sustained by poles and used for camping outdoors travel trailer means any portable unit designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel or recreational purposes the term travel trailer includes the following 1 an independent travel trailer which is a travel trailer containing toilet and lavatory facilities 2 a dependent travel trailer which is a travel trailer containing either toilet or lavatory facilities or having neither facility used or occupied means intended arranged or designed to be used for occupancy variance means the relaxation of the terms of the zoning regulations in relationship to building height size of the front rear and side yards and use of a property where the literal enforcement of these regulations could create unreasonable hardship but it is not contrary to the purposes of the city comprehensive plan and these regulations yard means an open space on the zoning lot which is unoccupied or unobstructed by any portion of a structure from the ground upward yard front front yard means an open space extending across the front of the lot between the side lot lines and extending from the front lot line to the front of the principal building or any projection thereof yard rear rear yard means an open space extending along the full length of the rear lot line between the side lot line and extending from the rear lot line to the rear of the principal building or projection thereof yard side side yard means an open space extending along a side lot line from the front lot line to the rear lot line extending from the side lot line to the side of the principal building or projection thereof part 2003    part 1997  part 1994            district boundaries and map   districts established in order to carry out the purposes and provisions of these regulations the following promote a suitable residential environment and to accommodate lowdensity detached singlefamily residential units uninterrupted by conflicting uses and incompatible activities for the rsf singlefamily residential district in promoting the general purposes of this title the specific intent of this section is a to encourage the construction or placement of and the continued use of the land for singlefamily dwellings in the city and extraterritorial area  b to prohibit highdensity residential commercial and industrial use of the land to prohibit any other use which would substantially interfere with development or continuation of singlefamily dwellings in the district  c to discourage any use which would generate traffic on minor streets other than normal traffic to serve residents of other property in the area and whether shall be permitted to continue or shall be discontinued b authority to continue any nonconforming building or use which existed lawfully and conforming at the time of adoption of these regulations and which has become nonconforming upon adoption of these regulations may be continued but if the nonconforming use or occupancy is discontinued for a period of more than twelve consecutive calendar months any subsequent use or occupancy of the premises shall be a conforming use or occupancy c change or expansion of use whenever the use of a building becomes located e restoration of damaged building whenever a building is destroyed or damaged by fire or other casualty to the extent of more than sixty percent of its replacement cost as determined by the marshall & swift cost manual it shall not be restored unless said building and use shall conform to all of the regulations of the district in which it is located in the event such damage or destruction is less than sixty percent of such replacement cost repairs or construction may be made within one year from the date of destruction f residential uses in nonresidential districts the
